GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 53.001  CONTROL OF WATERWORKS.



   (A)   The Department of Waterworks shall be abolished, and the Board
of Trustees of the Department shall be dissolved. The operation of the
Waterworks shall be returned to the Board of Public Works and Safety. The
effective date of the abolition of the Department of Waterworks was February
1, 1964, except that the Board of Trustees of the Department shall have no
authority from the date of passage of this chapter to make any contract,
obligations or promises which will create any liability on the part of the
city, without approval of the Board of Public Works and Safety.



   (B)   The Board of Trustees of the Department of Waterworks shall
turn over the possession, care and custody of all assets including real
estate, personal property, books and funds under its control to the Board of
Public Works and Safety. The assets shall include, but not be limited to, all
property turned over to the control of the Board of Trustees of the
Department by Res. 16-1963, passed by the Common Council of the city. All
bank accounts shall be transferred into the name of the Clerk-Treasurer of
the city.



(1982 Code, § 51.01)  (Ord. 1-1964, passed 1-14-1964)



§ 53.002  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CONSUMER.  The person, firm, corporation or association having an
interest, whether legal or equitable, sole or only partial, either as owner,
tenant or occupant, in any premise which is or is about to be supplied with
water by the Waterworks.



   PREMISE.  Any building under the same roof and belonging to the same
person, or any single piece of real estate, together with its buildings and
adjuncts, and which belongs to the same person. Each dwelling house together
with its outbuildings and appurtenances shall be considered a single piece of
real estate or a PREMISE within the meaning of this chapter.



   WATER WORKS.  The Brazil City Waterworks, municipally owned by the
city.



(1982 Code, § 51.10)  (Ord. 1-1964, passed 1-14-1964)




GENERAL REGULATIONS




§ 53.015  REQUIRED APPLICATION, METER DEPOSIT AND INITIAL CHARGE.



   (A)   All persons desiring to be supplied with water from the city
Waterworks at a property now connected with the mains, must apply in person,
or legal representative, at the Waterworks office for water, before using the
same.



   (B)   Each new customer of the Waterworks shall pay a meter deposit
of $25. This deposit is to be held by the city as a guarantee that water
bills will be paid on presentation of monthly or quarterly statements of the
same, the city to pay interest on all deposits at the rate of 5% per annum.
No interest shall be paid for less than 6 months.



   (C)   There shall be a charge of $15 for initiation of service at a
location where a water meter is not in service. No water shall be turned on
to any premises which are indebted to the Waterworks for work done or
material furnished, until the indebtedness has been paid, and provided
further, that no applicant shall be supplied with water for any purpose
whatsoever; who, at the time of application for same, is indebted to the
Waterworks for water previously supplied him or her until indebtedness shall
be have been paid.



(1982 Code, § 51.11)  (Am. Ord. 9-1981, passed 5-26-1981; Am. Ord. 16-1981,
passed 10-12-1981)



§ 53.016  TERM OF CONTRACT.



   Ordinary contracts for water supply service, unless otherwise
specified, expire in 1 year from date of the application, subject to the
following conditions and provisions. Contracts for metered water supply
service expire on the first of the month which follows the end of the first
year from date of application. All contracts shall continue in force by
renewal without act or notice from either party to the other, from year to
year, unless 30 days notice in writing is given by either party to the other
of a desire to terminate the contract.



(1982 Code, § 51.12)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.017  CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP.



   (A)   In the event of any change of consumer, located at any
premises, connected to the system of the Waterworks for water supply service,
the Waterworks shall be immediately notified, in writing, of the change
giving in notice the name and address of the new consumer, whereupon the
Waterworks shall require the new consumer to make application for water
supply service in the same manner as is provided for new service connections.



   (B)   In absence of an application by a new consumer, the use of the
Waterworks service, may at the option of the Waterworks, to be taken and
presumed to be an acceptance by the new consumer of all the contract
obligations of the preceding consumer with the Waterworks.



   (C)   In the event any consumer fails to notify the Waterworks, in
writing, of a change in occupancy of any premises connected for water supply
service, that consumer shall continue to be liable to the Waterworks for all
rates and charges accrued and accruing for the service, until either the end
of the contract period in which he or she may later notify the Waterworks of
his or her desire to cancel, or the Waterworks shall, of its own volition,
have canceled the contract with the consumer, but this clause shall not
preclude the Waterworks from also demanding, from the new consumer, the
payment of all or any charges and rates which shall, at the time of the
demand, be unpaid or unsecured, without regard to whether the same accrued
prior or subsequent to any change in occupancy or ownership.



   (D)   In no case of change of consumer shall the preceding consumer
be released from any contract obligations to and with the Waterworks until
the expiration of the contract period, properly terminated in accordance with
these rules, except at the option of the Waterworks, evidenced by a written
release from the Waterworks.



(1982 Code, § 51.13)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.018  REVIVING CANCELED CONTRACTS.



   Any contract which has been canceled cannot be revived, nor can service
thereunder, which has been discontinued, be resumed except at the option of
the Waterworks, and then only on further conditions as it may impose, and on
payment to the Waterworks or all charges and rates due and unpaid under the
canceled contract, together with the usual turn-on charges, and on the
payment of the water rates applicable under these rules.



(1982 Code, § 51.14)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.019  WHEN RATES FOR SERVICE BEGIN TO ACCRUE.



   When applications for water supply service is made, the service
together with the charges and rates therefor shall begin in accordance with
these rules on the date the water is turned on by the Waterworks.



(1982 Code, § 51.12)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.020  CANCELLATION OF CONTRACT AND DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.



   All contracts shall be subject to cancellation at the option of the
Waterworks, and service thereunder may be discontinued by the Waterworks for
any of the following reasons:



   (A)   For misrepresentations or concealment in the application as to
the premises or fixtures to be furnished with water supply service or the use
to be made of the service;



   (B)   For adding to the premises or fixtures, or to the use to be
made of the water supply service, without notice, in writing, to the
Waterworks, and first obtaining its written assent to the addition;



   (C)   For waste or excessive use of water through improper or
imperfect pipes, fixtures or appliances or in any other manner;



   (D)   For refusal or neglect to make or renew any advance payment,
if any is required by the Waterworks, or to pay bills for service rendered
when due, or for refusal or neglect to comply with any requirements of the
Waterworks as to meter or service connection maintenance, alteration or
renewal, or other requirements relating to the water supply service of the
Waterworks;



   (E)   For the use of water supply service for or in connection with
or for the benefit of any other premises or purpose than that described in
the application, where pipes or plumbing fixtures have been installed without
securing a permit therefor from the Waterworks, or where the arrangements of
the pipes or the plumbing fixtures are not in accordance with the rules of
the Waterworks;



   (F)   For any interference or tampering, whether by act or omission,
with the seals on any meter, or with any meter box or vault, or with service
pipes or valves or any seals thereon, or with the curb stop cock, or with any
appliance of the Waterworks or with any appliance of the owner, which was or
is required by the Waterworks for controlling or regulating the water supply
service. For the purpose of this rule, any interference or tampering by any
person whomsoever with any appliances used in connection with or for
controlling or regulating the water supply service to any premises shall be
construed and taken to be the act or omission of the consumer at the premises;



   (G)   For failure to maintain, protect and safeguard the meter in
working order satisfactory to the Waterworks, where the meter is owned by
either the consumer or the Waterworks;



   (H)   In cases of continued vacancy of the premises;



   (I)   For violation of any rule of the Waterworks;



   (J)   When there has been a change in occupancy of the premises, but
no application from the new consumer has been made and approved by the
Waterworks;



   (K)   When there has been a discontinuance of the use of the water
or of the service of the Waterworks;



   (L)   When the contract has been in any way terminated by the
consumer. Likewise, unless all bills, accounts and charges of the Waterworks
have been paid or until they are properly secured to the satisfaction of the
Waterworks;



   (M)   When any consumer refuses or neglects payment of any bills,
accounts or charges for or on account of the premises;



   (N)   When the consumer commits any act of bankruptcy or makes an
assignment for the benefit of creditors, or has made against him or her an
application for the appointment of receiver;



   (O)   When the Waterworks has been or is being defrauded in any way;
and/or



   (P)   When any consumer becomes irresponsible or on his or her death.



(1982 Code, § 51.16)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.021  SERVICE CONNECTIONS AND WATER CONNECTION PERMIT FEES.



   (A)   Service connections shall be installed only with a valid
permit. The service connection means the service pipe beginning at the
coupling on the water main ending at the meter well.



   (B)   The water works shall make the tap in the water main. It shall
be the responsibility of the consumer to expose the water mainline, set
saddle, install corporation stop and pay for the installation of service from
water main.



   (C)   Water connection permit fees shall be as follows:



      (1)   Permit fee for developments for multiple single family
home sites shall be $1.25 per linear foot of waterline to cover the cost of
reviewing construction drawings, issuing the permit and conducting periodic
inspections of the construction.



      (2)   Permit fee for site development to connect to water
mainline to a building or single family dwelling shall be as follows:



 


Size

 

Tap Fee




2 inch or less meter

 

$500




 



      (3)   The charge for a tap larger than the 2 inch meter shall
be the cost of labor, materials, power machinery, transportation and overhead
cost for installing the tap, but shall not be less than the charge for a
2-inch meter tap.



   (D)   Written application for all new service shall be made at City
Hall, specifying that the applicant will use water and pay for same at
scheduled rates of a period of at least 1 year, beginning within 90 days from
date of application; the application to be made on printed forms of the
Waterworks.



(Ord. 7-2005, passed 4-13-2005)



§ 53.022  REPAIRS, RENEWALS AND REPLACEMENTS.



   All repairs, renewals and replacements of small service connections,
originally furnished by the Waterworks, and not otherwise, shall be made by
the Waterworks free of charge, on notice, in writing by the consumer of any
requirement of the repairs, renewal or replacements. Where repairs to service
pipes or water fixture beyond service connections or the curb stop are
necessary, the consumer shall, without delay, employ a plumber licensed by
the Waterworks to do the work. Failure, refusal or neglect of the consumer,
to make repairs within 3 days after notice is sent by the Waterworks, shall
authorize the Waterworks to shut off the water and to discontinue the service
without further notice.



(1982 Code, § 51.18)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.023  SIZE OF SERVICE CONNECTION PRESCRIBED.



   The Waterworks in every instance reserves the right, at its option to
designate and prescribe the size of a service connection, either on original
installation of a new connection or on any renewal or replacement of any old
connection. The service pipe may be extended from the curb by any plumber
licensed by the Waterworks when the necessary permit has been secured.
Reasonable sizes shall be designated and prescribed.



(1982 Code, § 51.19)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.024  SEPARATE SERVICE CONNECTION FOR EACH PREMISE.



   Each separate premise shall have its separate and distinct service
connection, and in no case shall more than 1 premise be furnished with
service from 1 connection, except only in cases where, in the discretion of
the Waterworks, the conditions make this impossible or inadvisable, in which
event the Waterworks may permit the use of 1 service connection.



(1982 Code, § 51.20)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.025  ALL WATER SOLD BY METER MEASUREMENT.



   All water will be sold to consumer by meter measurement at the rate
established by the State Public Service Commission.



(1982 Code, § 51.21)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.026  MINIMUM CHARGE; ON RATE AND WHEN CHARGED AT REGULAR RATE.



   (A)   All metered service shall have a monthly charge of rate,
varying with and based upon the size of the meters installed as follows:

   (B)   If the whole amount of water used by the consumer in any 1
month does not, when charged at the regular schedule rate, amount to as much
as the minimum charge, the consumer shall pay the minimum charge for that
month and shall not be liable for any other charges for water consumed during
the month. When the amount of water used by any consumer in 1 month, charged
at the regular rate, amounts to as much or more than the minimum charge for
the meter through which the water is used, then the consumer shall pay for
the amount of water used at the regular rate and shall not be liable to the
Waterworks for any minimum charges for that month.



(1982 Code, § 51.23)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)

   (A)   Each user shall pay a minimum charge in accordance with the
following applicable size of meter installed for which the user will be

otherwise the gross rates shall be charged.



   (C)   If a person, firm, company or corporation is using water from
more than 1 meter, each meter shall be figured separately and not less than
the minimum rate shall be charged for each meter.



(1982 Code, § 51.24)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 9-1981,
passed 5-26-1981)



§ 53.028  PUBLIC FIRE PROTECTION RATES.



   (A)   The amount to be paid by the city for fire hydrant rental per
year is $ 200 per year.



   (B)   When the city desires water for flushing a city sewer which
has become clogged, and satisfactory notice is given the Waterworks by a city
official, that the water is desired, the Waterworks will send 1 of its people
to open a fire hydrant and put a hose valve on the same so that the water can
be controlled by the city employees without using the main valve on the fire
hydrant. The fire hydrant must be opened by an employee of the Waterworks. No
charge will be made for the water or the service.



(1982 Code, § 51.25)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 9-1981,
passed 5-26-1981)



§ 53.029  PRIVATE FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE RATES PER ANNUM.



   (A)   The following rates for private fire protection service are
based on the size of the service pipe entering the building or grounds and
which, in any way, are used for private fire protection such as hose
connection to stand-pipes, stand-pipes and fire hydrants.



   (B)   The rates for yearly service, payable in advance are:

   (C)   The amount to be paid for private fire hydrant service shall
be $200 per hydrant per year.



(1982 Code, § 51.26)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 9-1981,
passed 5-26-1981)




SPECIFIC REGULATIONS




§ 53.040  INSTALLATION SERVICE.



   All private fire protection service will be installed by the Waterworks
which will ascertain the best location for same and lay the pipe from the
street main to a point just inside the wall of the building or within the
building line of open yards, where buildings are set back from the building
line. The consumer will be charged for time and materials. The service will
be so installed that the water used therefrom will not flow through the meter
but will be separate and apart from the regular water service.



(1982 Code, § 51.27)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.041  SIZE OF SERVICE PIPE; UNDERWRITERS PUMP.



   In all cases the Waterworks shall decide the size of the service pipe.
In all cases where underwriters pumps are to be installed, a suction pipe
sufficient internal area to deliver a quantity of water equal to the full
rated capacity of the pipe will be allowed, and no enlargement of the suction
pipe inside the premises will be permitted. If, however, this service pipe is
run to a surge tank placed in close proximity to the pump, the full size of
the suction which the pump calls for may be run from the pump to the tank.



(1982 Code, § 51.18)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.042  NUMBER OF SERVICES.



   One service only will be allowed to any 1 building or premises unless
in the opinion of the Waterworks the general public fire protection will not
be jeopardized and more than 1 is absolutely necessary for the proper
protection of the premises. All fire equipment connected to the Waterworks
service shall be confined within the application, and where 2 or more
connections are made for 1 building or premises, they shall be kept
separated, unless special permission is obtained from the Waterworks to
connect the same in a manner to approved by it.



(1982 Code, § 51.29)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.043  TEST OF FIRE SERVICES.



   Whenever a fire service system is to be tested under the regulations of
the fire insurance underwriters, the consumer must notify the Waterworks of
the proposed test, naming the day and hour when the same is intended to be
made so that, if desired, the Waterworks may have an inspector present during
the test.



(1982 Code, § 51.30)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.044  CONTAMINATION OF WATER SUPPLY.



   Any fire protection system supplied with water from the Waterworks
service shall be supplied exclusively with the water, and no connection will
be allowed with any other system drawing its supply from any other source
whereby the Waterworks water supply may be contaminated by the failure to
close valves or leaking check valves, and no auxiliary or secondary suction
pipe to any underwriters pump taking water from wells, streams or other
sources whatever will be permitted. Any fire protection system using water
from wells, streams or sources other than the Waterworks service shall be
kept separate from any system supplied from the Waterworks service.



(1982 Code, § 51.31)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.045  INSPECTION; APPROVAL OF THE FIRE CHIEF; GUARANTEES.



   (A)   All fire service shall be subject to inspection by the
Waterworks from time to time, and the consumer shall give the inspectors all
reasonable facilities for making the inspections and any information
concerning the same that the inspector or the Waterworks may require. Care
will always be taken that inspections will be made with as little
inconvenience to the consumer or occupant as possible.



(1982 Code, § 51.32)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



   (B)   All applications for private fire protection shall be subject
to the written approval of the Chief of the Fire Department, who, in the
approval, shall state that in his or her opinion the public fire protection
will not be endangered by the connection proposed to be made by the
Waterworks when properly safeguarded by the placing of an indicator post
valve as near the main as possible, the valve to be under the control and
orders of the Chief of the Fire Department, at time of fires, with full
authority to close the valve.



(1982 Code, § 51.33)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



   (B)   (1)   The Waterworks in no manner guarantees to furnish a
proper quantity of water through the fire protection service nor does it
undertake to guarantee anything relative to the services, but it will
endeavor to maintain the efficiency of its service under all conditions.



      (2)   The granting of a permit for private fire protection is
under the express condition that the Waterworks shall not be considered or
deemed in any manner to have undertaken to extinguish fire or to protect any
person or property against loss or damage by fire or otherwise; the
Waterworks is not an insurer of persons or property and it shall be free and
exempt from any and all claims for damage on account of any injury to persons
or property by reason of fire, water, failure to supply water or pressure, or
for any other cause whatsoever, and, in the event of the destruction of the
premises of the consumer, the contract between the Waterworks and the
consumer shall immediately cease.



(1982 Code, § 51.34)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
53.999



§ 53.046  PLANS AND DRAWINGS.



   The consumer will furnish an accurate sketch showing the pipes, valves,
hydrants, connections and appurtenances on the premises of the consumer and
connected with the mains of the Waterworks and also an accurate sketch of any
other water pipe system and fixtures that may exist on the premises.



(1982 Code, § 51.35)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.047  EXTENSIONS OF MAINS AND INSTALLING PUBLIC HYDRANTS.



   (A)   On receipt of written instruction from the city, the
Waterworks will extend its water mains in graded streets and install fire
hydrants, all at its own expense, 1 fire hydrant to be installed,
approximately, for every 300 feet of water mains so ordered and extended.



   (B)   The Waterworks will extend its main in graded streets,
adjoining existing mains, when there is sufficient new business,
satisfactorily guaranteed in writing, to give an additional revenue of  $50
per annum for a period of 3 years for every 300 feet of mains so extended, in
making up the $50 for every 300 feet, the Waterworks will not include any
existing business or any premises that can be supplied from existing mains.
Under this arrangement the city may transfer fire hydrants from other
portions of the city, by paying the actual costs of moving the hydrants and
connecting the same to the new mains, and the city shall pay the rental for
the hydrants in their new locations instead of in the original locations.



   (C)   The Waterworks will also extend its mains into subdivision
where satisfactory arrangements can be made with realty companies or owners,
who are promoting the sale of real estate, on the basis of a guaranteed
return of $17.50 per annum, for a period of 5 years for each 100 feet of main
pipe extended.



(1982 Code, § 51.36)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.048  MONTHLY READINGS; BILLS; COMPLAINTS.



   (A)   Meters will be read monthly in the last week of each month,
and all bills shall become due and payable the first day of the following
month.



(1982 Code, § 51.37)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



   (B)   (1)   All persons regarding themselves overcharged can, by
applying to the Waterworks office within 15 days after their bills are due,
have their premises inspected or meter tested, examined and reread, but all
bills against which no complaints have been entered within the time shall be
considered correct, and must be paid without any change in the amount of same.



      (2)   All persons making complaints are required to get a
written acknowledgement of same from the Waterworks office showing the nature
and amount of the complaint. Without the written acknowledgement no complaint
will be considered.



(1982 Code, § 51.38)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
53.999



§ 53.049  DEFECTIVE METER.



   No bills will be calculated on the registration of any meter the
setting of which and the quality thereof has not met the approval of the
Waterworks, and the Waterworks reserves the right at any time to test any
meter in actual service. Should, on any test, a meter prove to be defective
it will be taken out of service at once and the charge for the water will be
adjusted by estimate.



(1982 Code, § 51.39)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.050  METERS NOT REGISTERING.



   If any meter stops registering the consumer will be charged for the
month, the average for the corresponding period in preceding years or months.



(1982 Code, § 51.40)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.051  CONSUMER RESPONSIBLE FOR ALL WATER REGISTERED.



   (A)   The consumer supplied through meter will be held responsible
for all water registered by the same and no reduction will be allowed on
account of leaks or wastage.



   (B)   There shall be no waste of water either to prevent freezing or
for any other purpose. Water will not be furnished where there are leaky
pipes or fixtures.



   (C)   When the conditions are found to exist, the supply will be
shut off until repairs are made.



(1982 Code, § 51.41)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.052  DISCONNECTION FOR LATE PAYMENT.



   (A)   It is the policy of the city to discontinue utility service to
customers by reason of nonpayment of bills only after notice and a meaningful
opportunity to be heard on disputed bills.  The city's form for application
for utility service and all bills shall contain, in addition to the title,
address, room number, and telephone number of the official in charge of
billing, clearly visible and easily readable provisions to the effect:



      (1)   That all bills are due and payable on or before the date
set forth on the bill; and



      (2)   That if any bill is not paid by or before that date, a
second bill will be mailed containing a cutoff notice that if the bill is not
paid within ten days of the mailing of the second bill, service will be
discontinued for nonpayment; and



      (3)   That any customer disputing the correctness of his bill
shall have a right to a hearing at which time he may be represented in person
and by counsel or any other person of his choosing and may present orally or
in writing his complaint and contentions to the city official in charge of
utility billing.  This official shall be authorized to order that the
customer's service not be discontinued and shall have the authority to make a
final determination of the customer's complaint.



   (B)   Requests for delays or waiver of payment will not be
entertained; only questions of proper and correct billing will be
considered.  In the absence of payment of the bill rendered or resort to the
hearing procedure provided herein, service will be discontinued at the time
specified, but in no event until the charges have been due and unpaid for at
least 30 days.



   (C)   When it becomes necessary for the city to discontinue utility
service to a customer for nonpayment of bills, service will be reinstated
only after all bills for service then due have been paid, along with a
turn-on charge in the sum of $20.



(1982 Code, § 51.42)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 9-1981,
passed 5-26-1981)



§ 53.053  SETTING OF METERS; DISTURBING METER.



   (A)   (1)   All meters shall be put in and connected up under the
direction and in conformity with the rules and regulations of the Waterworks,
whether placed on premises, in basement or in the street, the Waterworks
reserves the right to decide the location.



      (2)   When placed in premises where a hot water tank is used,
the meter must not be placed nearer than 20 feet of the hot water tank and a
good check valve must be placed in the supply pipe between the hot water tank
and the meter.



      (3)   If this rule is not complied with the consumer will be
charged with all damages to the meter caused by hot water.



(1982 Code, § 51.43)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



   (B)   (1)   No person, unless authorized by the Waterworks, shall
connect, disconnect, remove or repair or otherwise disturb any meter. The
Waterworks will repair all meters 2 inches and less in size free of charge.



      (2)   Actual cost of repairs on all meters larger than 2
inches will be charged to consumers having the meters.



(1982 Code, § 51.44)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
53.999



§ 53.054  CONSUMERS RESPONSIBLE FOR METERS AND ARRANGING PIPES.



   (A)   Consumers will be held responsible for any damage meters may
sustain from freezing (except where set in tree row), hot water or steam
settling back from the boiler or from any other cause, and any necessary
repairs resulting from the cause will be made at the expense of the consumer,
the charges to be paid to the Waterworks before water is turned on.



(1982 Code, § 51.45)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



   (B)   Before any meter is placed by the Waterworks, the consumer
shall, at his or her own expense, have pipes so arranged that all water will
pass through the meter.



   (C)   Consumers shall provide ready and easy access to their meters
so that they may frequently be read and examined by the Waterworks.



(1982 Code, § 51.46)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.055  ACCESS TO PREMISES.



   Through its proper officers the Waterworks shall, at all reasonable
hours, have a free access to all parts of premises to which water is supplied
for the purpose of making necessary examinations.



(1982 Code, § 51.47)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.056  TEMPORARY USERS



   All water furnished to temporary users on an unmetered basis shall be
charged for on the basis of the listed consumption rates as estimated by the
Waterworks Superintendent.



(1982 Code, § 51.48)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 9-1981,
passed 5-26-1981)



§ 53.057  USE OF FIRE HYDRANT.



   No person, except a duly authorized agent of the Waterworks or Fire
Department, shall open, for public or private use, any fire hydrant or take
water from any outlet whatever, unless the person shall first obtain
permission from the Superintendent of the Waterworks.



(1982 Code, § 51.49)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.058  CONNECTIONS TO WATER MAIN ON MAIN WATER PIPE; SPRINKLING.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, except a duly authorized
agent of the Waterworks, to make or attempt to make any extension of, or
connection with, or tap to any main, distributing pipe or service pipe of the
Waterworks system by which water is furnished by the Waterworks to any
consumer, whether the main or pipe is owned by the city or private
individuals.



(1982 Code, § 51.50)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



   (B)   (1)   The use of water for sprinkling purposes must be
limited to 4 hours per day, from 6:00 a.m. to 7:00 a.m. and from 5 p.m. to 8
p.m. in the evening. The use of water for sprinkling purposes outside of
these hours is positively prohibited. Sprinkling shall be by hand only and
the use of automatic sprinklers or a hose fixed on a support is positively
prohibited.



      (2)   During all alarms of fire and while the fire pressure is
on the pipe, the use of water for yard or street sprinkling is positively
prohibited, and violation of either of these rules will forfeit the right to
use of the water at the option of the Waterworks.



(1982 Code, § 51.51)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
53.999



§ 53.059  DISCONNECTING THE USE OF WATER.



   Persons desirous of discontinuing the use of the water must give notice
to the Waterworks office prior to the stopping thereof or they will be
charged until the notice is given.



(1982 Code, § 51.52)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931) 



§ 53.060  CONTROL OF STOP COCKS.



   (A)   (1)   Stop cocks will be placed at the curb of property
line and shall be under the exclusive control of the Waterworks.



      (2)   No person shall, without written authority from the
Waterworks, turn on the water to any service.



   (B)   This rule shall not prevent plumbers from testing their work,
but they must not in any case leave the water turned on without special
permit.



(1982 Code, § 51.53)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.061  LIABILITY OF WATER WORKS.



   In no case will the Waterworks be liable for damage for shutting off
the water to any consumer either while making repairs to mains or service
pipes, or for any violation of the rules and regulations of the Waterworks.



(1982 Code, § 51.54)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.062  BOILERS.



   (A)   Steam boilers and gas engines taking a supply of water
directly from the service pipe depending on the pressure of the pipe system
of the Waterworks for supplying the boilers under working pressure, will do
so at the risk of parties making attachments as the Waterworks will not be
responsible for any accident or damages.



   (B)   House boilers for domestic use must in all cases be provided
with vacuum valves to prevent collapsing when the water is cut off from the
distributing pipes, and for accidents or damages from the imperfect action of
the valves, the Waterworks will not be responsible in any case.



(1982 Code, § 51.55)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.063  TAPPING THE WATER MAINS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person except a properly qualified agent
of the Waterworks to enter on any alley or street, within the city, for the
purpose of laying service or distributing pipes or to do any plumbing in
connection with the Waterworks or the city in the streets or alleys, or dig
in any street or alley, for the purposes or to do plumbing in connection with
the Waterworks or to make any connection with any main distribution service
or other pipe belonging to or forming a part of the Waterworks system of the
city, until the person has procured a permit so to do.



(1982 Code, § 51.56)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
53.999



§ 53.064  CITY EMPLOYEES TO REPORT.



   It shall be the duty of everybody, and especially all city employees,
to report to the Waterworks all cases of leakage or waste of water or any
violation of the provisions of this chapter.



(1982 Code, § 51.57)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.065  FIXTURES FOR PUBLIC USE.



   Attachments of whatever kind made to the water pipes or other fixtures
belonging to the Waterworks, and intended for public use, shall be subject to
the same supervision, rules and regulations as are made for the protection of
the Waterworks against abuse, destruction and unnecessary use or waste of
water.



(1982 Code, § 51.58)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.066  STOP AND WASTE VALVE.



   All persons taking water must provide a stop and waste valve properly
located inside of building and have pipes so arranged that water can be drawn
from them in case of danger from frost.



(1982 Code, § 51.59)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
53.999



§ 53.067  INSTALLATION, REINSTALLATION OR TRANSFER OF METERS.



   (A)   Installation. The following rates are established as charges
for installation of meters:



 


Meter Size (Inch)

 

Rate

3/4-inch

1-inch

 
$250



1-1/2-inch

 
$300



2-inch

 
$350



3-inch

 
$800



4-inch

 
$1,200




 



   (B)   Reinstallation. When a meter is installed and ordered taken
out within 6 months from the date of the installation, a charge of $1,000
will be made for reinstalling the meter for the same customer.



   (C)   Transfer. The charge for transfer of a meter from 1 location
to another for use by the same customer is $15.



(1982 Code, § 51.53)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 16-1981,
passed 10-12-1981)



§ 53.068  PLUMBER REGULATIONS.



   (A)   No plumber shall be authorized to carry on the business of
plumbing in connection with the Waterworks until he or she has given
satisfactory bond in the sum of $1,000 and received a license as provided by
ordinance affecting plumbers.



   (B)   Plumbers will be required to have their bonds renewed on or
before January 1 of each year, otherwise their license will become
inoperative.



   (C)   No plumber shall lay any service pipe or do any kind or work
in connection with the introduction and supply or water without first having
obtained a written permit from the Waterworks for each separate job of
plumbing work which he or she may wish to perform. All plumbing must be done
subject to the approval of the Waterworks. Water closets and urinals must be
provided with self-flushing valves unless supplies through a meter.



   (D)   Plumbers shall make a full and complete return of the use for
which water is supplied under any permit granted. The return must be made by
the plumber doing the work within 48 hours after the completion of any work.



   (E)   If a plumber, in making an attachment or in shutting off or
turning on water, should not properly replace the curb box or in any way
injure any of the property of the Waterworks, he or she shall be charged with
the expense of making all necessary repairs. On his or her failure to report
the damage or pay the charges he or she shall be refused further permits
until the damages are paid.



   (F)   After testing any work, the plumber shall turn off the water
from the premises except where the work is a simple extension or addition
attachment on a service then in use and where a permit has been obtained to
make the same. Where water is turned off previous to making any alterations
or repairs, plumbers shall not leave water turned on when work is completed.



   (G)   Plumbers are particularly cautioned to leave curb cocks in the
condition in which they find them, either on or off. Disregard of this rule
will result in forfeiture of license.



   (H)   Plumbers shall report in writing to the Waterworks all repairs
to any water service within 48 hours after completion of the repairs. The
above specifically includes leaks.



   (I)   Plumbers shall not loan or sell any valve keys.



   (J)   All pipes used must be either standard weight cast iron,
properly coated, galvanized wrought iron or extra heavy lead. The use of
block wrought iron or steel pipe is prohibited.



   (K)   All work shall be inspected before being covered up, if
underground, and the plumber doing the work shall give and Waterworks at
least 2 hours notice that the work will be ready for inspection.



   (L)   Where services are metered no connection shall be made between
meters and curb box.



   (M)   Plans for fire protection lines or other special or unusual
uses shall be submitted to the Waterworks for approval before any work is
done in connection therewith.



   (N)   The cross connection of one premises with another, whether
owned by the same person or not, is strictly prohibited. Each property must
have its own individual curb cock.



   (O)   Any plumber violating any of the Waterworks rules and
regulations governing the introduction, supply and consumption of water or
who shall either voluntarily or at the request of any consumer or subscriber
introduce any pipe, hydrant, bath or fixture which is prohibited by the
Waterworks will be prosecuted and shall be subject to the penalties
hereinafter provided and may, at the option of the Waterworks Committee, be
required to forfeit his or her license to do plumbing.



(1982 Code, § 51.61)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.069  DUTIES OF THE SUPERINTENDENT.



   (A)   The Superintendent, under the direction of the Waterworks
Committee and the Common Council, shall have charge of the City Waterworks.



   (B)   It shall be his or her duty to see that all rules and
regulations are complied with; that the conditions of all contracts by or
with the city relating to the Waterworks are faithfully complied with; he or
she shall audit all accounts and claims and submit the same to the Waterworks
Committee with the information that will enable them to act advisedly
thereon; with authority from the Waterworks Committee; he or she shall
purchase all supplies for the City Waterworks.



   (C)   He or she shall keep a correct account of all persons using
water; he or she shall see that the accounts are kept according to the rules
of the State Public Service Commission, and report to it at least once a
year; he or she shall collect all the water rents and deposit same with the
City Clerk-Treasurer at least once each week.



(1982 Code, § 51.62)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.070  REBATE OF DEPOSITS.



   (A)   When the water is turned off, a rebate of the deposit made by
the consumer will be given after all bills of the Waterworks have been paid.
If the consumer moves out owing bills, the deposit will be used as a payment
of the bills. The deposit receipt must in all cases accompany the application
for rebate.



   (B)   The Superintendent shall pay the rebate due the depositor and
take a receipt for the same, and on filing a claim, with a receipt attached,
the Common Council shall reimburse the Superintendent for the money advanced
by him or her.



(1982 Code, § 51.63)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.071  SUPERINTENDENT TO MAKE CONTRACTS.



   The Superintendent is authorized and directed to execute, on behalf of
the city, all contracts for water and other contracts provided for in this
chapter, the same to be executed according to the terms and conditions
specified in this chapter. In the absence of a Superintendent the contracts
shall be executed by a duly authorized agent of the city.



(1982 Code, § 51.64)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.072  BYPASS THIEVERY.



   Any person found to have constructed or installed any device to
circumvent the metering of water flow shall be fined $2,500.



(1982 Code, § 51.66)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 53.073  UNLAWFUL USE OF WATER SERVICE LINE.



   (A)   Any person found to have used a city water service line or the
water therefrom without having the line or water metered and acting without
written permission of the City Waterworks Department in violation of this
section shall be fined $2,500; this section shall not preclude the Board of
Public Works and Safety from collecting from the person a reasonable sum for
water used in violation of this section, in addition to the fine herein
established.



   (B)   Any person violating this section, shall have his or her water
service discontinued until proper application for water service and meter has
been made and approved.



(1982 Code, § 51.67)  (Ord. 16-1981, passed 10-12-1981)



§ 53.074  DELINQUENT LOCATIONS.



   Any person making application for water service for a location from
which previous water or sewage accounts may be payable to the Waterworks
shall pay the account on the location prior to the provision of service to
the location in the name of the new account.



(1982 Code, § 51.68)  (Ord. 16-1981, passed 10-12-1981)



§ 53.075  RECONNECTION CHARGE; CUSTOMER METER DEPOSIT.



   (A)   Reconnection charge.



      (1)   To establish a new service connection or to re-establish
service for an account or customer that had not previously had service
disconnected for non-payment within the previous 12-month period prior to the
request-$15.



      (2)   To re-establish service for an account or customer who
previously had the service discontinued because of non-payment within the
previous 12-month period prior to the request-$35.



      (3)   For each re-establishment of service within a 12-month
period for non-payment the service re-establishment charge shall increase by
$35 for each subsequent re-establishment after disconnection for non-payment
within a 12-month period.



      (4)   When the service is turned off for non-payment of bill
or whenever for any reason, beyond the control of the Waterworks, a
re-establishment of services is required by any 1 customer, the charge will
be made by the Waterworks to cover the cost of discontinuance and
re-establishment of service. The charge together with any arrears due the
Waterworks shall be paid by the customer before service will be
re-established.



   (B)   Customer meter deposit; lawn meter fee.



      (1)   A customer making application for service and who shall
be responsible for the monthly billings shall pay a "meter deposit" in the
amount of $60.



      (2)   A customer making application for service and who shall
be responsible for the monthly billings who has never before been a customer
for service shall pay a meter deposit in the amount of $100, $40 of which
shall be refunded after 1 year of continuous service.



      (3)   For all customers making application for service and who
shall be responsible for the monthly billings, any deposit paid less any
amount of the current and/or delinquent bill owing shall be refunded to the
customer at a time as the customer requests disconnection or termination of
respective service.



      (4)   In regard to "lawn meters" the fee for a lawn meter
shall be $100, $50 of which shall be refunded to the customer when the lawn
meter is returned to the city at disconnection or termination of services in
regard to the use of lawn meters.



(Ord. 11-2004, passed 5-25-2004)



§ 53.999  PENALTY.



   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter
shall, on conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not less than $5 nor more
than $50 for each offense.



(1982 Code, § 51.68)  (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
