CHAPTER 70:  GENERAL PROVISIONS



Section




Generally




   70.01   Definitions



   70.02   Police Department’s duty to enforce traffic regulations



   70.03   Obedience to Police Department officials required



   70.04   Notification of violation; filing of citation



   70.05   Parking in certain areas restricted




Speed Bumps and Other Speed Modifications




   70.15   Mandatory procedures governing speed control modifications



   70.16   City agencies involved



   70.17   Content of written requests and role of affected residents



   70.18   Design and construction of speed control modifications



   70.19   Notice and hearing requirements of Board initial
determination



   70.20   Role of Board of Public Works and Safety



   70.99   Penalty




GENERALLY




§ 70.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLE.  Vehicles of the Fire Department, state
and county and municipal police departments, and ambulances when on emergency
calls, shall be considered authorized emergency vehicles.



   INDIVIDUAL PARKING SPACE.  A portion of the paved surface of the
street of sufficient length or depth from the sidewalk curb to accommodate a
vehicle to be parked, as shall be specified and marked off by the Board of
Public Works and Safety.



   INTERSECTION.  The area embraced within the prolongation of the
lateral curb lines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of 2 or more
streets or highways which join one another at an angle whether or not 1 of
the streets or highways crosses the other.



   OPERATOR.  Any person in actual control of any vehicle.



(1982 Code, § 70.01)



   PARKING.  The standing of a vehicle on a street whether the vehicle is
occupied or not and whether the vehicle is occupied or not by an operator for
a period of time in excess of 2 minutes.



(Ord. 6-1980, passed 5-2-1980)



   PEDESTRIAN.  Any person afoot.



   SILENT POLICE OFFICER.  Any suitable device, safety zone, post, sign,
standard or automatic signal light placed within any street or public place
as a warning or for control or direction of traffic.



   TRAFFIC OFFICE.  The police headquarters of the city.



(1982 Code, § 70.01)



   VEHICLE.  Any motor vehicle, automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer,
semitrailer, truck tractor, bus, school bus, recreational vehicle,
construction vehicle, tractor and bicycle.



(Ord. 8-1984, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 70.02  POLICE DEPARTMENT'S DUTY TO ENFORCE TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Police Department of this city to
enforce the provisions of this chapter. Officers of the Police Department are
authorized to direct all traffic either in person or by means of visible or
audible signal in conformance with the provisions of this chapter, provided
that in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to
safeguard pedestrians, officers of the Police or Fire Departments may direct
traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this
chapter.



   (B)   The Police Department is empowered to make and enforce
regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter, to
make and enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies.



(1982 Code, § 70.10)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 70.03  OBEDIENCE TO POLICE DEPARTMENT OFFICIALS REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse or to fail to comply with
any lawful order, signal or direction of a police officer.



(1982 Code, § 70.11)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
70.99



§ 70.04  NOTIFICATION OF VIOLATION; FILING OF CITATION.



   (A)   Whenever a member of the Police Department shall observe
violations by the operator of any vehicle of §§ 70.03, 71.01 through 71.04,
73.01 through 73.13 and Ch. 74, Sch. II, the officer shall notify the
operator in writing by the issuance to the violator a citation stating the
violation, the license number plus make and year of the vehicle, the
violator's name and address, the violator's drivers license number, the date
and location of the violation and the date of initial court appearance. The
original citation shall be filed in the Clay County Superior Court or any
other proper court of competent jurisdiction to hear ordinance violations in
the City of Brazil. A copy of the citation shall also be filed in the office
of the City Clerk-Treasurer who will forward the same to the city attorney
for prosecution.



   (B)   Whenever a member of the Police Department shall observe
violations by any person of any other provisions of this title not
specifically set forth in division (A) above, the officer shall notify the
operator in writing by the issuance to the violator a citation stating the
violation, the license number plus make and year of the vehicle, the
violator's name and address (if available) and the date and location of the
violation. The original citation shall be filed at the office of the City
Clerk-Treasurer. The violator shall present himself or herself with the copy
of the citation at the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer for the purpose of
paying the proper penalty within 72 hours after the date of issuance. If the
violator fails to appear and pay the appropriate penalty, the Clerk-Treasurer
shall notify the city attorney who shall file, or cause to be filed, in the
Clay County Superior Court or other court of competent jurisdiction to hear
ordinance violations, an affidavit charging the violator with the violation
specified in the citation.



   (C)   Whenever a member of the Police Department shall observe
violations of any provisions of Chapter 73 of the Brazil Code, the violators
and citations shall be processed pursuant to the provisions of division (A)
above.



(Ord. 7-2002, passed 5-14-2002)



§ 70.05  PARKING IN CERTAIN AREAS RESTRICTED.



   (A)   Parking of certain types of trailers as hereinafter defined on
the streets within the corporate limits of the city, with a zoning district
designation as an “R District-Residential” as provided for under the
Zoning Code is restricted in that no person shall stop, stand or park certain
types of trailers as defined herein, upon any street within an “R
District-Residential” area designation under the Zoning Code and within the
corporate limits of the city, except as follows:



      (1)   While expeditiously loading or unloading passengers,
freight, materials or merchandise between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00
p.m.;



      (2)   While affecting emergency repairs when a vehicle is so
disabled as to render it unsafe to proceed further;



      (3)   Vehicle and equipment engaged in street construction,
maintenance and repair, or the construction, maintenance or repair of public
service utilities;



      (4)   Vehicles serving as emergency vehicles.



   (B)   The term semi-trailer as used in this section, applies to
semi-trailers defined as a trailer that is in excess of 25 feet in length and
is the type of trailer that has wheels only at the rear, requiring the front
end to be supported by a towing vehicle, which is not an automobile, a van, a
mini-van, SUV, or a pickup truck. Measurements for length shall be the
overall length of the trailer, including the hitch, if it extends beyond the
trailer body.



   (C)   Any trailer as defined herein found stopped, standing or
parked in violation of any provision of this section is subject to being
removed and impounded at the owner's expense.



   (D)   This section incorporates by reference Chapter 74, which may
further restrict parking in regard to the streets contained within the
corporate limits of the city. Further, parking may further be restricted by
the rest and remainder of the sections contained in this title.



(Ord. 14-2006, passed 4-25-2006)  Penalty, see § 70.99




SPEED BUMPS AND OTHER SPEED MODIFICATIONS




§ 70.15  MANDATORY PROCEDURES GOVERNING SPEED CONTROL MODIFICATIONS.



   The following procedure must be strictly followed before a speed bump
or other traffic or speed control modifications of the surface or grade of
any public street or alley way can be constructed or made by any elected or
appointed officials of the City of Brazil, and any employee or agent of the
City of Brazil or by any contractor or citizen of the City of Brazil.



(Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)



§ 70.16  CITY AGENCIES INVOLVED.



   A written request shall be submitted by the Supervisor of the City
Street Department to the Board of Public Works and Safety (hereinafter
referred to as "Board.") Prior to submission, the request shall be submitted
to the Chief of the Police Department for investigation and approval. The
Chief shall sign the request either approving or disapproving the request,
and state the reasons therefore if the Chief determines or desires to
recommend modifications or alternative to the written request, he or she may
do so thereon prior to signing the same.



(Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)



§ 70.17  CONTENT OF WRITTEN REQUESTS AND ROLE OF AFFECTED RESIDENTS.



   (A)   The request shall state the actual location of the proposed
placement or removal of the speed bump or speed control modification, and the
reason therefor.



   (B)   Accompanying the request shall be a written approval for the
proposed placement, removal or modification signed by at least 75% of the
residents located within the block of the proposed modification plus those
located at least 1 block of either side of the affected block.



(Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)



§ 70.18  DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF SPEED CONTROL MODIFICATIONS.



   Any speed bump or speed control modification must be so designed and
constructed that a traveling vehicle may proceed over the same at the speed
of at least 20 mph without causing damages to the vehicle or severe jarring
of the driver thereof, or, in the alternative, in compliance with state or
nationally approved design requirements therefor.



(Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)



§ 70.19  NOTICE AND HEARING REQUIREMENTS OF BOARD INITIAL DETERMINATION.



   (A)   Upon the submission of the written request, the Board shall
advertise for and hold a public hearing on the request which shall be open to
the public. Published notice of the hearing shall be placed in a newspaper of
general circulation within the city pursuant to I.C. 5-3-1.



   (B)   At the conclusion of the public hearing, the Board shall
determine whether to approve or deny the request and so indicate its reasons
for its decision. A majority of the Board is necessary for approval of the
request.



(Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)



§ 70.20  ROLE OF BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AND SAFETY.



   Following 6 months after the placement, removal or modification of the
street or alleyway as approved by the Board, the Board shall advertise for
and hold a public hearing which shall be open to the public to review its
initial determination and to receive public input regarding that
determination. Following that hearing, the Board may reverse, modify or
affirm its initial determination if it determines that the public welfare and
safety are adversely affected thereby.



(Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)



§ 70.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating the provisions of this title shall be
subject to a civil penalty of $12. The violator shall also be responsible for
court costs for any violations filed in court in addition to the civil
penalty.



   (B)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day that
a violation occurs or continues.



   (C)   Any vehicle illegally parked shall be subject to being
removed, towed and stored at the owner's expense.



(Ord. 7-2002, passed 5-14-2002)



CHAPTER 71:  TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES



Section



   71.01   Obedience to traffic-control devices



   71.02   Traffic-control signal legend



   71.03   Interference with official traffic-control devices prohibited



   71.04   Establishment of safety zones, bus stop zones and taxicab
stands



   71.99   Penalty



§ 71.01  OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.



   It shall be unlawful for any operator of any vehicle to disobey the
instructions of any official traffic sign, or signal placed in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise directed by a police
officer.



(1982 Code, § 70.20)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
71.99



§ 71.02  TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNAL LEGEND.



   (A)   At all places where the silent police officers are placed,
drivers or operators of vehicles shall be controlled by the warning or
direction given thereby.



   (B)   Whenever traffic at an intersection is alternately directed to
proceed and to stop by the use of automatic colored lights or the words "GO"
or "CAUTION" and "STOP" these lights are terms shall indicate as follows:



      (1)   GREEN or GO.  Traffic facing the signal may proceed,
except that vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and
vehicles lawfully within a crosswalk or the intersection at the time the
signal was exhibited.



      (2)   CENTER or MIDDLE YELLOW or CAUTION.  When shown
following the green or "GO" signal. Traffic facing the signal shall stop
before entering the intersection unless so close to the intersection that a
stop cannot be made in safety.



      (3)   RED or STOP.  Traffic facing the signal shall stop
before entering the intersection and remain standing until the green or "GO"
signal is shown.



(1982 Code, § 70.21)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 71.03  INTERFERENCE WITH OFFICIAL TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully deface, injure, move,
obstruct or interfere with any official traffic sign or signal.



(1982 Code, § 70.22)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see 71.99



§ 71.04  ESTABLISHMENT OF SAFETY ZONES, BUS STOP ZONES AND TAXICAB STANDS.



   (A)   The Common Council's Committee on Public Safety is empowered
to establish safety zones of a kind and character and at places as they may
deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians.



   (B)   Safety zones shall be marked off and indicated by painted
lines, discs, standards or loading platforms.



   (C)   The Committee shall also have the power to establish bus stop
zones and taxicab stands.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle at any time
to drive the same through or over or to the left of any safety zone so
established as herein provided.



(1982 Code, § 70.23)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
71.99



§ 71.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter for which no
penalty is otherwise provided, shall be fined subject to a civil penalty of
not less than $65 and not more than $200.



   (B)   The penalty for the first violation shall be $65; for the
second violation $100; and for each subsequent violation $200.



   (C)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day that
a violation occurs or continues.



(Ord. 6-1994, passed 5-24-1994)



CHAPTER 72:  MOVING TRAFFIC VIOLATION DEFERRAL PROGRAM



Section



   72.01   Program User Fund



   72.02   Program established



   72.03   User fees established



   72.04   Payment of Traffic Violation Deferral Program fees



   72.05   Usage of funds from the Program



   72.06   Duration of Program



§ 72.01  PROGRAM USER FUND.



   There is created a Moving Traffic Violation Deferral Program User Fund
within the City's Department of Law Budget.



(Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)



§ 72.02  PROGRAM ESTABLISHED.



   It is the desire of the city attorney in agreement with the Brazil
Police Department to create and establish a Moving Traffic Deferral Program
pursuant to I.C. 34-28-5-1, whereby any person charged with a moving traffic
violation pursuant to the ordinances of the City of Brazil may enter the
Deferral Program by executing a written deferral agreement and paying
required user fees in lieu of admitting the violation or having the violation
tried before the court in which the violation charge is filed.



(Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)



§ 72.03  USER FEES ESTABLISHED.



   Pursuant to I.C. 34-28-5-1 and 33-39-1-8 any person charged with a
moving traffic violation pursuant to the ordinances of the City of Brazil and
agreeing to enter into the Deferral Program shall be required to pay an
initial user's fee of $50 and a monthly user's fee of $10 as part of the city
attorney's Deferral Program agreement.



(Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)



§ 72.04  PAYMENT OF TRAFFIC VIOLATION DEFERRAL PROGRAM FEES.



   (A)   The initial and monthly user's fees shall be collected by the
court in which the violation is filed pursuant to I.C. 34-28-5-1.



   (B)   The Clerk of the Court shall transfer collected Deferral
Program user's fees to the City Clerk-Treasurer within 30 days after they are
collected pursuant to I.C. 33-37-5-17, and the Clerk-Treasurer shall deposit
those fees into the Moving Traffic Violation Deferral Program User Fund
created by this chapter.



(Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)



§ 72.05  USAGE OF FUNDS FROM THE PROGRAM.



   The city attorney shall have control over the use of the collected
Deferral Program user fees in the fund. At his or her discretion, the funds
may be dispersed therefrom to fund requested needs and equipment for the
Brazil Police Department or the Department of Law in the administration of
the Deferral Program or the prosecution of moving traffic violation
ordinances.



(Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)



§ 72.06  DURATION OF PROGRAM.



   (A)   The Moving Traffic Violation Deferral Program User Fund shall
be perpetual until terminated at the request of the city attorney pursuant to
this chapter.



   (B)   This fund may be terminated at the request of the city
attorney by the enactment of an ordinance and any fund balance in that fund
shall be transferred to the city's general fund to be used for any purposes
lawfully allowed.



(Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)



CHAPTER 73:  TRAFFIC RULES AND REGULATIONS



Section




Generally




   73.01   Stop required before emerging from an alley, private drive
or building



   73.02   Overtaking and passing vehicles



   73.03   Operating vehicles on approach of emergency vehicle



   73.04   Hanging on or attaching to vehicles



   73.05   Crossing fire hoses



   73.06   Soliciting rides prohibited



   73.07   Driving through funeral or other processions prohibited



   73.08   Following emergency vehicles restricted



   73.09   Load limits



   73.10   Traction engines and heavy machine restrictions and
requirements; liability



   73.11   Obstructing traffic and open exhaust or cut-outs prohibited



   73.12   Crossing streets, turn and U-turn regulations



   73.13   Riding on sidewalks restricted




Speed Limit Regulations




   73.25   Maximum speed limits established



   73.26   Unlawful to exceed maximum speed limits




Truck Route Regulations




   73.40   Findings by the City of Brazil



   73.41   Role of the Common Council



   73.42   Authority to establish regulations addressing truck routes



   73.43   Specific truck routes established



   73.44   State Road 59 and U.S. 40 truck traffic




Emergency Vehicle Lanes




   73.55   Purpose



   73.56   Definitions



   73.57   Designation and establishment procedures



   73.58   Stopping, standing and parking prohibited



   73.99   Penalty




GENERALLY




§ 73.01  STOP REQUIRED BEFORE EMERGING FROM AN ALLEY, PRIVATE DRIVE OR
BUILDING.



   It shall be unlawful to drive a motor vehicle from any alley, driveway
or building into any public street without first bringing the vehicle to a
full stop at or immediately before the edge of the improved surface of the
street.



(1982 Code, § 71.01)  (Ord. 10-1970, passed 10-13-1970)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.02  OVERTAKING AND PASSING VEHICLES.



   (A)   The operator of a vehicle shall not overtake and pass on the
left of any street or interurban car proceeding in the same direction,
whether actually in motion or temporarily at rest.



   (B)   The operator of a vehicle overtaking any street or interurban
car stopped or about to stop for the purpose of receiving or discharging any
passenger shall stop the vehicle at a distance not less than 6 feet from the
rear thereof and shall keep the vehicle stationary until any passenger has
boarded the vehicle or reached a place of safety, except that where a safety
zone has been established, a vehicle need not be stopped before passing any
vehicle, but may proceed past the vehicle with due caution for the safety of
pedestrians.



   (C)   The drivers in meeting other vehicles shall pass to the right
thereof and in overtaking other vehicles shall pass on the left side of the
vehicle overtaken.



(1982 Code, § 71.02)  (Ord. 10-1970, passed 10-13-1970)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.03  OPERATING VEHICLES ON APPROACH OF EMERGENCY VEHICLE.



   (A)   Authorized emergency vehicles are given the right-of-way over
all other vehicles.



   (B)   On the approach of any authorized emergency vehicle giving
audible signal by bell/horn or siren and/or having its emergency lights
flashing, the operator of every other vehicle shall immediately drive the
same to a position as near as possible and parallel to the right-hand edge or
curb of the highway, clear of any intersection.



   (C)   The operator/driver shall stop and remain in that position
until the authorized emergency vehicle shall have passed, unless otherwise
directed by a Police or Fire Department officer.



   (D)   The operator/driver shall not drive the same into any street
intersection if Police or Fire Department or other authorized emergency
vehicle are approaching the street intersection within 500 feet thereof.



(1982 Code, § 71.03)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.04  HANGING ON OR ATTACHING TO VEHICLES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person traveling on any bicycle,
motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle to cling to, or
attach himself or herself or his or her vehicle to any other moving vehicle
on any highway in the city.



(1982 Code, § 71.05)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931;)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.05  CROSSING FIRE HOSES.



   No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the Fire
Department when laid down on any street, private driveway to be used at any
alarm of fire, without the consent of the Fire Department official in command.



(1982 Code, § 71.06)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.06  SOLICITING RIDES PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to stand in a highway for the
purpose of soliciting a ride from the operator of any private vehicle.



(1982 Code, § 71.07)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.07  DRIVING THROUGH FUNERAL OR OTHER PROCESSIONS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle, or bus to drive
the same between the vehicles comprising a funeral procession or any
authorized civic, military or public procession while the vehicles comprising
the procession are in motion, provided that the vehicles are conspicuously so
designated.



(1982 Code, § 71.03)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.08  FOLLOWING EMERGENCY VEHICLES RESTRICTED.



   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to follow closer
than 300 feet to any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or
to drive into or stop any vehicle within 1 block where the fire apparatus has
stopped in answer to a fire alarm.



(1982 Code, § 71.09)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.09  LOAD LIMITS.



   During the months of February, March and April of each year, the Board
of Public Works and Safety is authorized and instructed to have posted load
limits imposed on certain streets in the city as is appropriate to prevent
damage from being done to the street from heavy vehicles.



(1982 Code, § 71.10)  (Ord. 11-1966, passed 4-26-1966)



§ 73.10  TRACTION ENGINES AND HEAVY MACHINE RESTRICTIONS AND REQUIREMENTS;
LIABILITY.



   (A)   It is made unlawful for any person in charge of any traction
engine, or other heavy machine likely to injure any paved street in the city,
to drive or run the same on, over or along any paved street in the city,
except as provided this section.



   (B)   When it shall become necessary in the movement of any traction
engine, or other heavy machine, to pass the same over any paved street
crossing, the person in charge of the same shall apply to the city engineer
for a permit to run the engine or machine over the paved crossing.



   (C)   The engineer, before permitting the passage of the engine or
machine over a paved crossing shall require the person in charge thereof to
lay heavy planks over the crossing on which the engine or machine shall be
moved and the same shall be done in a manner so as to effectually protect the
paved crossing from injury and should injury occur to any paved street or
crossing by reason of an engine or machine passing over the same, then the
owner of the engine or machine shall be liable to the city for the injury,
notwithstanding the permit.



(1982 Code, § 71.11)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.11  OBSTRUCTING TRAFFIC AND OPEN EXHAUST OR CUT-OUTS PROHIBITED.



   (A)   All vehicles traveling or being driven at a slow rate of speed
shall keep as near as possible to the proper side of the street so that other
vehicles driven at a higher rate of speed may pass the same on the left-hand
side without inconvenience and so as to obstruct as little of the side of the
street as is reasonably possible, and facilitates public travel.



   (B)   The driving of a motor vehicle with the exhaust or cut-out
open and unmuffled is strictly forbidden.



(1982 Code, § 71.12)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.12  CROSSING STREETS, TURN AND U-TURN REGULATIONS.



   The drivers of motor vehicles and other vehicles shall not cross any of
the streets or turn a vehicle therein, except at street intersections, and
complete, full or U-turns shall not be made on National Avenue at its
intersection with the following named streets: Forest Avenue, Washington
Street, Sherfey Street, Walnut Street, Franklin Street and Meridian Street.



(1982 Code, § 71.13)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99



§ 73.13  RIDING ON SIDEWALKS RESTRICTED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive any horse or mule,
or to drive any wagon or other vehicle hitched to any horse, or mule, or to
run or drive any automobile, motorcycle or other motor vehicle, or to ride
any bicycle on, along or across any sidewalk in the city, unless the same be
done in the necessary act of crossing the sidewalk, and it shall also be
unlawful for any person to hitch any animal in a manner as that the same may
get on any sidewalks.



(1982 Code, § 71.14)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
73.99




SPEED LIMIT REGULATIONS




§ 73.25  MAXIMUM SPEED LIMITS ESTABLISHED.



   (A)   The maximum speed limit for any motor vehicle being operated
on any public street, alley or public way located within the corporate limits
of the City of Brazil, shall be 25 mph, unless otherwise posted.



(Ord. 10-1997, passed 5-27-1997)



   (B)   A 20 mph speed zone is established for vehicular traffic on
Jackson Street, from Vandalia Street east to the corporate limits of the city.



(Ord. 2-1987, passed 2-24-1987)



   (C)   The speed zone for vehicular traffic in Forest Park and George
Craig Park shall be 5 mph.



(Ord. 7-1987, passed 7-14-1987)



   (D)   There shall be a 20 mph speed zone on Hendrix Street from
State Road 59 to Murphy Avenue; and on Murphy Avenue from Hendrix Street to
U.S. 40, with the Street Department installing proper speed zone signs.



(Ord. 16-1988, passed 6-28-1988)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.26  UNLAWFUL TO EXCEED MAXIMUM SPEED LIMITS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operation a motor
vehicle on any public street in excess of 25 mph, unless a different speed is
otherwise posted.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle
on any public street, alley or public way located within the corporate limits
of the City of Brazil in excess of the posted speed limit.



(Ord. 10-1997, passed 5-27-1997)  Penalty, see § 73.99




TRUCK ROUTE REGULATIONS




§ 73.40  FINDINGS BY THE CITY OF BRAZIL.



   The City of Brazil has determined that the streets and roads within the
corporate limits of the city are not capable of handling commercial truck
traffic.



(Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)



§ 73.41  ROLE OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.



   The Common Council of the City of Brazil deems it appropriate to
designate certain streets within the city limits of the City of Brazil under
the jurisdiction of the Common Council of the City of Brazil to be used for
commercial truck traffic.



(Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)



§ 73.42  AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH REGULATIONS ADDRESSING TRUCK ROUTES.



   The Common Council of the City of Brazil has the authority to establish
a truck route pursuant to I.C. 9-20-1-3.



(Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)



§ 73.43  SPECIFIC TRUCK ROUTES ESTABLISHED.



   A truck route is established within the City of Brazil whereby
commercial trucks weighing in excess of 3 tons shall be limited to the use of
Hendrix Street east of Waterworks Road to Murphy Avenue and Murphy Avenue
south of Hendrix Street to U.S. 40; U.S. 40 west to Alabama Street, south on
Alabama Street to Pinckley Street and Pinckley Street west to Chicago Avenue;
then north to 40, then east to Depot Street and north on Depot Street to
Hendrix Street.



(Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)



§ 73.44  STATE ROAD 59 AND U.S. 40 TRUCK TRAFFIC.



   This subchapter shall in no way supersede laws of the State of Indiana
in regard to the use of State Road 59 or U.S. 40 for the purposes of truck
traffic.



(Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)




EMERGENCY VEHICLE LANES




§ 73.55  PURPOSE.



   It is deemed necessary for the public health and safety that emergency
vehicle lanes be designated and properly marked and posted at or adjacent to
buildings being used or occupied for multi-family residences, or for business
or commercial purposes; that nonemergency type vehicles be prevented from
being parked or left standing in a designated emergency vehicle lanes so that
police, fire and other emergency or rescue vehicles have free and
unobstructed access to bush buildings in order to perform their respective
emergency functions either being impaired by other vehicles parked adjacent
to these buildings as they normally contain large numbers of people who may
quickly need emergency service or evacuation from them during an emergency.



(1982 Code, § 72.20)  (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Am. Ord. 17-1981,
passed 10-12-1981)



§ 73.56  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BUILDING BEING USED OR OCCUPIED FOR MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENCES OR FOR
BUSINESS OR COMMERCIAL PURPOSES.  Any apartment, condominium, high-rise
building or structure used for multi-family housing; any building or
structure used for business office, wholesale or retail and industrial
purposes; and any shopping center or mall project.



   EMERGENCY or EMERGENCY SITUATION.  Any occurrence or event which
endangers the health and safety of persons which results in personal injury
damage to real or personal property, and which violates the personal rights
and privileges of innocent people, including but not necessarily limited to
the commission of any crime or law violation, a working fire in or near a
building or structure, any occurrence which necessitates immediate medical
attention or first aid treatment and any occurrence which necessitates the
evacuation of persons from any building or structure to avoid personal injury.



   EMERGENCY VEHICLE.  Any police patrol car or investigation vehicle,
police prisoner (paddy) wagon, police explosive protection truck and any
other vehicle owned by the City Police Department used for responding to
police emergencies or calls, any fire truck, aerial ladder, pumper or snorkel
fire suppression truck or other fire suppression apparatus, fire
investigation or prevention automobile or truck, and rescue truck owned by
the City Fire Department used for responding to working fires and other
fire-related emergencies; any ambulance, emergency medical or paramedic
vehicle, county police vehicle, state police vehicle, volunteer fire
department vehicle or apparatus, civil defense vehicle and Red Cross vehicle
used for responding to emergency situations.



(1982 Code, § 72.21)  (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Am. Ord. 17-1981,
passed 10-12-1981)



§ 73.57  DESIGNATION AND ESTABLISHMENT PROCEDURES.



   (A)   Whenever the owner, manager, tenant or occupant of any
building being used or occupied for multi-family residences, or for business
or commercial purposes desires to establish adjacent to the building
designated emergency vehicle lanes, or the Fire Chief, after investigation
determine that emergency vehicle lanes are vital and necessary for the
protection of the building and the health and safety of persons therein, the
Fire Chief shall inspect the location and determine the areas thereof to be
designated as emergency vehicle lanes and notify the owner, manager, tenant
or occupant of the building as to location thereof as well as the proper
method of designating the location of signs to notify the public of the
existence of the emergency vehicle lanes.



   (B)   The owner, manager, tenant or occupant of the building must
first request in writing to the Fire Chief his or her desire to establish
emergency vehicle lanes at the building and an inspection for the purpose of
determining the necessity, feasibility and location of lanes.



   (C)   Following an inspection, the Fire Chief shall determine the
need for emergency vehicle lanes and notify in writing the owner, manager,
tenant or occupant of the building as to the proper location of the lanes.



   (D)   The owner, manager or tenant of the building shall be
responsible for having the curb (if one exists in the designated emergency
vehicle lane area) painted yellow, along with the posting and maintenance of
signs placed at or within the emergency vehicle lane area at least 5 feet
high which indicate that the area is an emergency vehicle lane, the exact
location of the lane and that the stopping or parking of a vehicle in that
area is prohibited except for emergency vehicles.



   (E)   The owner, manager, tenant or occupant of the building is
responsible for requesting in writing to the Police Chief that the officers
of the Police Department patrol the area of the building and the designated
emergency vehicle lanes, and enforce the provisions of this subchapter
pertaining to the prohibition of any nonemergency vehicle from stopping or
parking in the lanes if the lanes are located on private property. The Police
Department has no authority to enter on private property for purposes of
enforcing this subchapter without this written permission of the owner,
manager, tenant or occupant thereof.



(1982 Code, § 72.22)  (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Am. Ord. 17-1981,
passed 10-12-1981)



§ 73.58  STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to cause or permit any vehicle, other
than emergency vehicles responding to an emergency situation, to stop, stand,
park or remain in any designated emergency vehicle lane established pursuant
to this subchapter obstructing the access and free passage of any emergency
vehicle responding to an emergency situation or performing an emergency
function.



   (B)   A person operating a non-emergency vehicle may stop or park
the vehicle for a period not to exceed 10 minutes for the sole purpose of
loading or unloading a handicapped or otherwise physically incapacitated
person, and once the loading or unloading of a person has been accomplished,
the vehicle must be removed from the area.



(1982 Code, § 72.23)  (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Am. Ord. 17-1981,
passed 10-12-1981)  Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Generally. Any person violating any provision of this chapter
for which no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99



   (B)   Speed limits. Any person violating the provisions of §§
73.25 or 73.26 shall be fined a civil penalty of $12 plus court costs as
established by the court pursuant to this chapter.



(Ord. 10-1997, passed 5-27-1997)



   (C)   Truck routes. A fine of not less than $10 and not more than
$100 shall be levied against operators of any commercial vehicle violating
§§ 73.40 through 73.44.



(Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)



   (D)   Emergency vehicle lanes.



      (1)   Any person violating the provisions of §§ 73.55
through 73.58 shall be guilty of a Class C infraction and subject to a
penalty of $5 and any vehicle so illegally parked shall, at the officer's
discretion, be subject to being removed, towed and impounded at the owner's
expense.



      (2)   If the penalty is not paid within 10 days from the date
of the offense, the penalty shall be $10.



      (3)   If the penalty is not paid within 30 days from the date
of the offense, the violator shall be summoned into court and be subject to a
fine of up to $500.



      (4)   If a person is issued a second or subsequent citation
for violation of §§ 73.55 through 73.58 within a period of 1 year, the
vehicle shall be towed at the owner's expense and impounded.



(1982 Code, § 72.99)  (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Am. Ord. 17-1981,
passed 10-12-1981)



CHAPTER 74:  PARKING SCHEDULES



Schedule



   I.   Handicapped/disabled parking



   II.   Loading zones and parking areas



   III.   Municipal parking lots; restricted parking times and areas



   IV.   Parking prohibited at all times



   V.   Parking prohibited at limited times



   VI.   Loading zones



   VII.   Bus zones (commercial and school)



   VIII.   Parallel parking



   IX.   Restricted parking in congested areas



   X.   Parking clearance



SCHEDULE I.  HANDICAPPED/DISABLED PARKING.



   (A)   (1)   The following locations shall be designated as
"Handicapped Parking Only," and it shall be unlawful for any person to park
any vehicle in an area designated for handicapped parking only unless that
person has been issued a valid handicapped person license plate or other
lawful handicapped designation located thereon.



      (2)   A designated handicapped parking only location shall be
identified by the placement of 1 sign at the beginning of the designated
location stating "HANDICAPPED PARKING ONLY" and the curb shall be painted
blue, indicating the length of the designated parking space.



(Ord. 14-2005, passed 6-16-2005)



   (B)   The following locations shall be designated as a handicapped
parking location, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle
in these locations unless that vehicle has a valid handicapped license plate
or other lawful handicapped designation located thereon or therein.



 


Street

 

Location





Lambert Street
 
One parking space in front of 621 S. Lambert Street


South Lambert
 
In from 603 South Lambert Street


South Sherfey Street
 
First parking space on west side, south of US 40 intersection


South Sherfey Street
 
Last parking space on the west side before intersection with Jackson Street


East Tennessee Street
 
On the south side of Tennessee, located on the north side of 855 North Forest
Avenue


East Vermont Street
 
On the north side in front of 426 East Vermont Street


Walnut Street
 
One parking space in front of 1126 N. Walnut Street




 



(Ord. 4-1999, passed 4-27-1999)  (Ord. 26-2004, passed 10-12-2004)  (Ord.
14-2005, passed 6-16-2005; Am. Ord. 13-2006, passed 4-11-2006; Am. Ord.
24-2006, passed 8-8-2006)



   (C)   (1)   Whoever violates any provisions of this schedule for
which no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be fined a civil penalty of not
less than $65 and not more than $200.  The penalty for the first violation
shall be $65; for the second violation $100; and for each subsequent
violation $200.



      (2)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
that a violation occurs or continues.



      (3)   Any vehicle illegally parked shall be subject to being
removed, towed and stored at the owner's expense.



(Ord. 4-1999, passed 4-27-1999)



SCHEDULE II.  LOADING ZONES AND PARKING AREAS.



   (A)   Loading zones; how designated. The Board of Public Works and
Safety is authorized and empowered to designate certain spaces or zones on
the streets and thoroughfares on the city, to be designated as loading zones.



(1982 Code, § 72.01(A))  (Ord. 2-1957, passed 4-23-1957)



   (B)   Restricted parking in loading zones.



      (1)   No vehicle shall be parked or left standing whether
occupied or not, within the boundaries of marked-off areas, designated as a
loading zone, unless the driver of that vehicle is making a delivery of, or
providing repairs or services for the premises of business places, or
receiving items of merchandise or personal property used in the normal course
of business by merchants or business persons within the city block wherein a
loading and unloading zone is located.



      (2)   Parking shall not be deemed to be within the meaning of
this section, unless that motor vehicle is left standing for a period of time
longer then is necessary to accomplish the purpose of loading and unloading.



(1982 Code, § 72.01(B))  (Ord. 2-1957, passed 4-23-1957)



   (C)   Angle parking. In parking motor vehicles and other vehicles
along the side of all streets and avenues in the city, parking shall be
parking flat along and within 1 foot of the curb.



 


Street

 

Side

 

Between

 

Requirement



Harrison Street
 
West
 
National Avenue and Jackson Street
 
See division (C) above


Alabama Street
 
Both
 
National Avenue and Jackson Street
 
In addition to division (C) above, shall be parked with the front end to the
curb, at an angle of 35 degrees with the curb.



 



(1982 Code, § 72.10)  (Ord. 9-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 3-1935,
passed 4-9-1935)



   (D)   Double parking and parking for repairs along street restricted.



      (1)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle double in the
city, or to park any vehicle on any of the streets or avenues of the city in
any other manner than as specifically provided for in this chapter.



      (2)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for the purpose
of repairs or service at any point along National Avenue in the city if and
when repairs shall render the motor vehicle unable to be moved away under its
own power.



      (3)   These provisions are enacted for the purpose of
providing greater safety and to prohibit unnecessary fire hazards.



(1982 Code, § 72.12)  (Ord. 9-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  (Am. Ord. 3-1935,
passed 4-9-1935)



   (E)   Parking prohibited on any tree row. No motor vehicle shall be
parked on any tree row in the city.



(1982 Code, § 72.13)  (Ord. 9-1931, passed 9-22-1931)

   (G)   Parking meter fund and fees.



      (1)   All parking meter fees and license fees collected from
mechanical parking devices, commonly known as parking meters, used and
operated in the city, shall continue to be deposited with the
Clerk-Treasurer, to the credit of the city, in a special fund, which the
special parking meter fund shall be disbursed and paid out only under the
orders and directions of the Board of Public Works and Safety or the Common
Council.



      (2)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall be entitled to receive, and
shall be paid, additional compensation for keeping records and handling
parking meter fees collected and expended; which compensation shall be in
addition to all other compensation received by the Clerk-Treasurer. The
additional compensation shall be paid solely and only out of the special
parking meter fund.



      (3)   All other monies in the parking meter fund shall
continue, as heretofore, to be used an expended solely and only for the
payment of the cost of parking meters, the maintenance and repair of parking
meters and the repair and maintenance of any of the public streets and
highways, where any parking meters are used, and all other public streets and
highways connected therewith in the city.



      (4)   All of the parking meter funds received by the city are
appropriated for the uses and purposes provided in this section.



(1982 Code, § 72.02)  (Ord. 4-1953, passed 7-21-1953)



   (H)   Penalties for parking in prohibited areas.



      (1)   Any person violating the provisions of division (D)
above or Schedule I of this chapter shall be guilty of a Class C infraction
and shall be subject to a penalty of $5, and any vehicle in violation thereof
shall be subject to being removed, towed and impounded, at the owner's
expense.



      (2)   If the above penalty is not paid at the office of the
Clerk-Treasurer within 10 days from the date of the violation, the penalty
shall be $10.



      (3)   If the penalty is not paid within 30 days form the date
of the violation, the violator shall be summoned into court and be subject to
a judgment of up to $500.



(Ord.13-1992, passed 9-8-1992)



SCHEDULE III.  MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS; RESTRICTED PARKING TIMES AND AREAS.



   (A)   Restricted parking.



 


Parking

 

Restriction



Public parking by any vehicle on 4 parking spaces
 
Limited to 30 minutes between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Monday through
Saturday, except holidays



 



   (B)   Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



      PARKING.  The standing of a vehicle on the municipal parking lot
whether the vehicle is occupied or not, and whether the of 2 is occupied or
not by an operator.



      VEHICLE.  Any motor vehicle, automobile, motorcycle, truck,
trailer, semi-trailer, truck-trailer, bus, school bus, recreational vehicle,
construction vehicle, tractor and bicycle.



   (C)   Penalty. Whoever violates any provisions of this schedule
shall be fined the sum of $25. A public offense shall be deemed committed for
each violation that occurs or continues to occur for a period in excess of 2
hours and a vehicle illegally parked shall be subject to being removed, towed
and stored at the owners expense.



(Ord. 2-1985, passed 4-9-1985)

SCHEDULE IX.  RESTRICTED PARKING IN CONGESTED AREAS.



   These streets shall be declared a congested traffic area, and the
Common Council determines that because of the flow of traffic on the streets
or portions of the streets within this area that parking therein shall be
subject to the following provisions:



   (A)   The Board of Public Works and Safety is authorized and
directed to designate and mark off individual parking spaces as it deems
proper along the streets in the congested traffic area for the parking of
vehicles. At each place where individual parking spaces are so marked off,
each vehicle shall be parked entirely within an individual parking space; and



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or
suffer any vehicle registered in the name of, or operated by, any person to
be parked in any individual parking space within the congested traffic area
for a period of more than 2 consecutive hours, during the hours of 8:30 a.m.
to 4:30 p.m., inclusive, and between the days of Monday through Friday,
inclusive, except holidays.



 


Street

 

Between

 

Location





National Avenue
 

Alabama and Sherman Streets

 

-



Walnut Street
 

-

 

Within 1 block of National Avenue



Sherfey Street
 

-

 

Within 1 block of National Avenue





 



(1982 Code, Schedule X)  (Ord. 24-1966, passed - -)  Penalty, see § 10.99

SCHEDULE VIII.  THROUGH STREETS.



   (A)   The streets and avenues referred to in this schedule are
declared to be through or preferential streets for the purpose of regulating
traffic on or crossing the same and every operator of a vehicle or other
conveyance traveling on any street or roadway intersecting any through
street. Operators/drivers shall bring their vehicle to a full complete stop
at the place where the street meets the prolongation of the nearest property
line of a through street, subject, however, to the direction of any official
traffic-control sign or signal or the directions of any police officer at the
intersection.



   (B)   The operator of any vehicle who has come to a full stop as
required above, on entering the through street, as well as operator of
vehicles on a through street, shall be subject to the usual right-of-way rule
prescribed by state law governing the meeting of vehicles at street or
highway intersections.



   (C)   The Common Council's Committee on Public Safety is authorized
to place and maintain or cause to be place of maintained on each and every
street intersecting a through street as designated above, and at or near the
property line of the through street, appropriate signs on or near the street
(and in addition thereto may place and maintain any appropriate device or
mark in or near the highway)  signs, devices or marks to bear the word
"STOP" or the legend "STOP THRU STREET" or the legend "STOP THRU STREET,
POLICE ORDERS."



   (D)   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to
disobey any signs, signals or devices erected by order of the Committee of
the Common Council.



(1982 Code, § 71.04)  (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)

constitute through streets.

this section. The violator shall also be responsible for court costs for any
violations filed in court in addition to the civil penalty.



      (2)   Whoever violates any provision of this schedule shall be
subject to a civil penalty of $200. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues.



      (3)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
that a violation occurs or continues.



      (4)   Any vehicle illegally parked shall be subject to being
removed, towed and stored at the owner's expense.



(Ord. 13-2003, passed 11-11-2003)

GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 90.01  CITY'S AUTHORITY TO REGULATE.



   The city may regulate the conduct, or use or possession of property
which might endanger the public health, safety or welfare of its citizens.



§ 90.02  AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH A POLICE AND A FIRE DEPARTMENT.



   (A)   The city may establish, maintain and operate a police and law
enforcement system to preserve public peace and order and may provide
facilities and equipment for that system.



   (B)   The city may establish, maintain and operate a fire fighting
and fire prevention system and may provide facilities and equipment for that
system.



§ 90.03  CITY’S AUTHORITY TO REGULATE AIR AND SOUND.



   The city may regulate the introduction of any substance or odor into
the air, or any generation of sound.



§ 90.04  AUTHORITY TO REGULATE PUBLIC GATHERINGS.



   The city may regulate public gatherings such as shows, demonstrations,
fairs, conventions, sporting events and exhibitions.



§ 90.05  OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH, ORDER AND DECENCY.



   All offenses against public health, order and decency not addressed by
this code shall be governed by applicable state statute.



§ 90.06  RESISTING OFFICIAL ACTION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to knowingly or
intentionally interfere, or attempt to impede or interfere with any city
official or employee in the performance of his or her official duties.



Penalty, see § 90.99




REFUSE, GARBAGE AND TRASH REGULATIONS




§ 90.20  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   HEAVY TRASH.  Any discarded matter which cannot be adequately placed
or wrapped in commercially manufactured plastic garbage or trash bags because
of its size or weight and shall include but not necessarily be limited to
appliances, water heaters, furniture, mattresses, box springs, bicycles,
furnace or air conditioning units, metal duct or pipe, large tree limbs, all
other items which are either too large or too heavy to be securely wrapped in
bags as described above herein. Specifically excluded from this definition
are tires, rocks and building or construction materials such as roofing,
bricks, concrete blocks, lumber and automotive parts.



   TRASH or GARBAGE.  Any discarded matter including but not necessarily
limited to household refuse, paper, glass, food containers, edible food or
portions thereof, waste materials, cut grass, weeds or tree limbs or leaves,
wrappings, metal items or other items of personal property.



(Ord. 9-1992, passed 7-21-1992)



§ 90.21  PROHIBITING ACCUMULATION OF OPEN TRASH AND GARBAGE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person who owns or rents private
residential property, multi-family dwellings or mobile homes within the
corporate limits of the city to permit or allow the accumulation of open
trash and garbage on the property.



(1982 Code, § 93.11)  (Ord. 55-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 18-1981,
passed 10-26-1981)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.22  MONTHLY TRASH COLLECTION PROCEDURE; FEE.



   (A)   Effective February 1, 2007 (utility bills due February 10,
2007), every person who either owns or rents residential property,
multi-family dwelling units or mobile homes within the corporate limits of
the city, whose property lies outside the corporate limits and along North
Murphy Avenue to Hendrix Street, Hendrix Street, Hendrix Street to Murphy
Avenue, all property in Deer Creek Subdivision, or any other property located
in the corporate limits of the city with the approval of the Board of Public
Works and Safety shall be charged a monthly trash collection fee in the
amount of $10.50 per household to be added as a separate charge on his or her
monthly water bill and payable at the City Waterworks office.



(Ord. 29-2004, passed 11-24-2004; Am. Ord. 39-2006, passed 12-28-2006)



   (B)   Excluded from this fee are business and commercial concerns,
and governmental entities.



   (C)   (1)   If a residential owner or occupant does not pay the
monthly trash collection fee within 60 days after it becomes due, the city
shall discontinue the collection service to that residential unit, and it
will be the obligation of the owner or occupant to either make other
arrangements for trash collection and removal or pay the past due fees plus a
continuation of service charge of $10 for resumption of city service to that
residence.



      (2)   Failure to pay the collection fee for a period of 18
months after it becomes due shall result in the city attaching a lien on the
applicable real estate as an additional assessment to the property taxes
applicable thereto.



(1982 Code, § 93.12(B)(C))



   (D)   No person shall place, put or deposit any trash, garbage,
waste or rank elements, either placed in any type of container or bag, or any
empty trash container or bag in any tree row, street or on that person’s
property or residence in a manner so that it is visible from a public street,
except for the designated collection day each week or the designated heavy
trash collection day and no earlier than the day before any designated
collection day.  Furthermore, all containers or empty trash containers shall
be removed from the tree rows, sidewalks, street or on that person’s
property or residence in a manner so that it is visible from a public street
by the end of the person’s normally or re-scheduled trash collection day if
the trash collection day falls during the week of a city authorized and
approved holiday.



(Ord. 2-2005, passed 2-9-2005)



§ 90.23  TRASH COLLECTION FUND.



   (A)   The collected fees shall be deposited in a separate fund and
identified as the Trash Collection Fund, and only the costs of operation and
maintenance, of the service shall be paid from the fund.



   (B)   Any net accumulated surplus after payment of operational and
maintenance costs shall be retained to pay for future increases in costs,
replacement of or additions to trash collection equipment or future
reductions of the trash collection fee by ordinance.



(1982 Code, § 93.12(D))



§ 90.24  MONTHLY REPORTING TO COMMON COUNCIL.



   The City Waterworks shall receive an amount equal to 6% of the total
monthly fee collected to cover its costs of collection, computation and
billing and a monthly report to the Common Council of customers in arrears in
their payments and discontinuations in services.



(1982 Code, § 93.12(E))



§ 90.25  PERIODIC REVIEW OF COLLECTION FEE REQUIRED.



   The amount of the monthly trash collection fee shall be periodically
reviewed by the Common Council and the Mayor and no more than 24 months shall
elapse without a review.



(1982 Code, § 93.12(F))  (Ord. 18-1981, passed 10-26-1981; Am. Ord. 5-1982,
passed - -)



§ 90.26  WEEKLY TRASH COLLECTION.



   For residential premises and all multi-family dwelling units and mobile
homes located and situated inside the corporate limits of the city, trash
collection by the city shall occur once each week.



(1982 Code, § 93.13(A))



§ 90.27  BI-ANNUAL HEAVY TRASH COLLECTION.



   (A)   Heavy trash collection shall occur a minimum of twice each
year, once during the spring of the year and once during the fall, plus at
any other time deemed necessary by the Mayor.



   (B)   Collection will occur for 1 week for each quadrant of the city
after proper advertisement in a local newspaper at least 7 days prior to the
designated day.



   (C)   Residents wishing heavy trash collection shall notify the
Waterworks office by telephone at least 24 hours prior to the designated
heavy trash collection day.



(Ord. 9-1992, passed 7-21-1992)



§ 90.28  TRASH CONTAINER REGULATIONS.



   (A)   All ordinary and usual trash and garbage to be collected shall
be packed and securely contained in commercially available plastic bags and
be light enough in weight for 1 person to conveniently lift, and the maximum
of 10 bags will be collected from any 1 residence or residential unit.



   (B)   Garbage or trash in paper sacks, wrapped in paper, or in
cartons shall not be collected.



   (C)   Loose and open trash and garbage shall not be collected.



(1982 Code, § 93.13(C))



§ 90.29  EXCLUDED ENTITIES.



   Trash collection shall not be made at business or commercial
establishments and non-city governmental entities, including but not limited
to county hospitals and schools.



(1982 Code, § 93.13(D))  (Ord. 19-1981, passed 10-26-1981)



§ 90.30  HOURS OF OPERATION FOR COMMERCIAL, INDUSTRIAL, AND/OR BUSINESS
ENTITIES.



   Every person, firm, corporation, partnership, or sole proprietorship
engaged in the business of hauling, carrying and/or collecting trash, debris,
garbage, or rubbish from commercial, industrial, and/or business entities
(including apartments) that lies adjacent to any property zoned for R-1, R-2,
or R-3 uses or any property that is zoned T but whose use is that of a
residential nature, shall conduct the business within the city's corporate
limits between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m.  The  business shall
not be conducted after 10:00 p.m. or before 6:00 a.m.



(Ord. 17-2006, passed 6-13-2006)  Penalty, see § 90.99




BURNING REGULATIONS




§ 90.40  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ADEQUATE FIRE FIGHTING EQUIPMENT.  Equipment sufficient and
appropriate under the circumstances to extinguish a fire.



   CEREMONIAL FIRE.  A fire set for the purpose of celebrating an event,
such as an athletic victory, special church holiday or other special
occasion; an example being a bonfire.



   CLEAN PETROLEUM PRODUCTS.  An uncontaminated refined petroleum
product, such as kerosene, lighter fluid, charcoal lighter fluid or diesel
fuel, not previously used in any application.



   CLEAN WOOD PRODUCTS.  Wood or wood products, including vegetation,
that are not coated with stain, paint, glue or other coating material.



   GARBAGE.  All organic household waste, offal, animal and vegetable
matter whose prepared or intended use is as food, condemned foodstuffs and
materials, and substances, materials and things ordinarily disposed of in
containers and/or incinerators by hotels, restaurants, stores, hospitals,
apartment houses and private dwellings.



   MATERIALS CONTAINING ASBESTOS.  Materials such as asphalt, roofing
shingles, vinyl siding, insulation, plastics, wiring, floor tile or any other
matter or material with which asbestos is attached to, added to or made a
part of that matter or material.



   OPEN BURNING.  The burning of any materials wherein air contaminants
resulting from combustion are emitted directly into the air without passing
through a stack, chimney, duct or pipe, from an enclosed chamber, and
includes above ground or underground smoldering fires, including, but not
limited to, household trash, garbage, refuse, outdoor waste, foliage,
branches, leaves, plastic and building materials, waste materials and waste
substances, tires, treated wood, materials containing asbestos, clean
petroleum products, clean wood products, paper and charcoal.



   PUBLIC NUISANCE.  An occurrence, act, course of conduct or use of
property, which interferes with the rightful use and enjoyment of the
property of others, or injurious to health, or indecent or offensive to the
senses of persons within the neighborhood, the entire community or the public
generally.



   RECREATIONAL FIRE.  A fire set for the purpose of a cookout, barbeque
or a fire set for the purpose of cooking or preparing food for human
consumption, or a campfire used for Boy or Girl Scouting purposes or in
relation with scouting activities or historical re-enactments.



   TREATED WOOD.  Wood or wood products coated or saturated with arsenic,
chromium, copper or creosote.



(Ord. 5-2002, passed 6-11-2002)



§ 90.41  OPEN BURNING PROHIBITED.



   (A)   The open burning of household trash, garbage, refuse, outdoor
waste, foliage, branches, leaves, plastic and building materials, waste
materials and waste substances, tires, treated wood and materials containing
asbestos, within the corporate limits of the City of Brazil, Indiana is
hereby declared a public nuisance and is hereby prohibited.



   (B)   No fire intended or used as a recreational or ceremonial fire,
as authorized in § 90.42 below shall be used for the purposes of disposing
of any household trash, garbage, refuse, outdoor waste, foliage, branches,
leaves, plastic and building materials, waste materials and waste substances,
tires, treated wood or materials containing asbestos.



(Ord. 5-2002, passed 6-11-2002)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.42  RECREATIONAL OR CEREMONIAL FIRES.



   (A)   Recreational or ceremonial fires, such as fires for outdoor
cooking, barbeques, campfires, fires for scouting activities or other social
activities of organizations, such as schools, fraternal or church
organizations, shall be permitted within the corporate limits of the City of
Brazil, Indiana subject to the following terms and conditions.



      (1)   These fires shall be fueled only by clean wood products,
paper, charcoal or clean burning petroleum products, such as lighter fluid.
An electric lighter device, a charcoal chimney or newspaper may be used as
lighting aids.



      (2)   Fires must be attended at all times by a person at least
18 years of age until it is completely extinguished.



      (3)   If at any time, a recreational or ceremonial fire
creates a public nuisance, such as a pollution problem, a threat to public
health, a dangerous fire hazard to nearby structures, persons, trees, foliage
or utility lines, the fire shall be immediately extinguished.



      (4)   No burning of any kind shall be conducted during
unfavorable weather or meteorological conditions such as high winds,
temperature inversions or air stagnation, or when a pollution alert or ozone
action day has been declared by the appropriate governmental agency.



      (5)   All permitted open burning shall comply with other
federal and state laws and regulations.



      (6)   Adequate firefighting or suppression equipment shall be
on-sight of any recreational or ceremonial fire sufficient to extinguish the
fire.



      (7)   Fires shall not be ignited prior to 2 hours before the
recreational or ceremonial activity is to take place, and they shall be
extinguished completely at the conclusion of the activity.



      (8)   The wood or other proper substance used as fuel for a
recreational fire used for cooking or barbeques, or as a campfire, shall be
less than and no greater than 2 feet in height and 4 feet in diameter.



      (9)   Any ceremonial fire shall be less than and no greater
than 1,000 cubic feet.



      (10)   Only 1 fire sight may be burning at a time at a
location.



      (11)   A ceremonial fire shall not take place within 500 feet
of any fuel storage area or pipeline, within 100 feet of a frequently
traveled street or roadway.



   (B)   Any person desiring to have a recreational or ceremonial fire
pursuant to this section shall register with the Brazil Police Department
dispatch personnel on duty and state the name of the person or organization
conducting the fire, the purpose of the fire, the location of the fire and
the starting and ending times of the activity associated with the fire.



   (C)   Any member of the Police Department or the Fire Department
shall have the right to inspect the location of any recreational or
ceremonial fire, the size of the fire, the supervision of the fire and the
effect of the fire on the adjoining or nearby residents and the general
neighborhood of the fire, and the compliance with this section, with or
without a complaint being registered regarding the fire.



   (D)   The Fire Department may extinguish or authorize the
extinguishing of any recreational or ceremonial fire which violates any
provision of this chapter or any other federal, state or local law,
regulation or rule, or is creating a public nuisance.



(Ord. 5-2002, passed 6-11-2002)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.43  VIOLATIONS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for
any person, group, organization, including school, fraternal or church
organization, to cause, have, conduct or allow open burning within the
corporate limits of the City of Brazil, Indiana in violation of § 90.41.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any
person, group, organization, including school, fraternal or church
organization, to cause, have, conduct or allow an open burning recreational
or ceremonial fire within the corporate limits of the City of Brazil,
Indiana, in violation of § 90.42 above.



(Ord. 5-2002, passed 6-11-2002)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.44  BURNING OF TRASH, GARBAGE, REFUSE AND LEAVES PROHIBITED.



   The burning of trash, garbage, refuse, foliage, branches, leaves or
waste materials or waste substances within the City of Brazil, Indiana is
declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited.



(Ord. 9-1984, passed 11-13-1984)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.45  EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   This subchapter shall not be enforced against any person or
persons engaged in burning of any type of charcoals, woods or other type of
combustible product for the purpose of cooking, home heating or social
activities of school, fraternal or church organizations.



   (B)   These regulations shall not be enforced against any person who
first gives written notice to the City of Brazil and the city fails to pick
up trash, refuge, foliage, branches, leaves and other waste materials within
5 days of notice.



   (C)   This exclusion from prohibition does not pertain to persons
engaged in business within the corporate limits of the City of Brazil at his
or her place of business, or an employee thereof.



(Ord. 9-1984, passed 11-13-1984)




MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS




§ 90.60  FIRING GUN WITHIN CITY; EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   It is declared unlawful for any person to fire any gun or
pistol in the city.



   (B)   This provision shall not be construed to extend to any police
officer, nor to any peace officer while in the performance of any duty in
pursuance of any ordinance, or in obedience to any law of the state.



(1982 Code, § 130.03)  (Ord. 16-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
90.99



§ 90.61  GIVING FALSE ALARM IN PUBLIC PLACE PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to strike a match, or to cry out
"fire" in a church, hall or theater, while the church, hall or theater is
occupied by a public assemblage, or to utter any cry tending to create a
panic in the city.



(1982 Code, § 130.04)  (Ord. 12-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
90.99



§ 90.62  LITTERING REGULATIONS.



   (A)   The City of Brazil, having received complaints from the
residents of the City of Brazil concerning certain litter violations
occurring in and on city streets, a $500 fine shall be the penalty for any
person who litters on a street located in the City of Brazil.



   (B)   The City Street Department is directed to install sign
locations giving notice of anti-littering regulations on each U.S. 40 city
limit west, U.S. 40 city limit east, Indiana 59 city limit north and Indiana
59 city limit south.



(Ord. 6-1991, passed 8-13-1991)



§ 90.63  CONTROL OF PUBLIC ASSEMBLIES AND GROUPS.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of every owner, proprietor, manager or
person in control of any theater, opera, moving picture show, public
entertainment or public assembly, to keep the aisles and ways of ingress and
egress to and in the room where people are assembled, by chairs, persons or
other unobstructed obstructions of any kind or character, so in case of that
fire or any other emergency, the aisles in the room and the exits therefrom
will be unobstructed, and thereby facilitate the escape of persons from the
room. The failure to perform that duty is declared unlawful.



   (B)   It is declared unlawful for any person to obstruct the aisles
in any theater, opera, moving picture show public entertainment or other
public assembly, or the exits therefrom, by congregating or standing therein,
or in any other manner, to the end that aisles and exits shall be free and
unobstructed so that persons in the room in case of fire or other emergency,
may escape therefrom without any delay.



   (C)   In every room used for theatrical, operatic or moving picture
show purposes, or for public entertainments or public assemblies, the word
"Exit" shall be painted in plain English language, not less than 8 inches in
length, over each door or place of egress, and every word "Exit" shall have
over the same a red light at times when the room is being used for public
gatherings. The light shall be in relation to the word "Exit" that the light
will be reflected thereon, so that the word "Exit" may be seen by all persons
in the room whenever the room is in use for any of the purposes aforesaid.



   (D)   It shall be the duty of every owner, proprietor, manager or
person in control of any moving picture show to cause to be constructed and
maintained from the film room, in which the films are operated, an air tight
flue or duct 14 inches in diameter to the outside of the auditorium or
assembly room in order that all fumes and smoke may pass through the duct or
flue from the film room to the outside of the auditorium or assembly room in
case of fire, and not escape into the auditorium or assembly room, so that
the danger of persons breathing the poisonous fumes and gases and smoke will
be prevented, and it shall be unlawful to conduct any moving picture show or
operate any film unless the room in which the film is operated shall be
connected with the outside of the auditorium or assembly room by and with a
flue or duct and it be so arranged and constructed that the fumes and smoke
and gases resulting from the burning of the film, or other matter in the film
room, will pass through the duct to the outside of the auditorium or assembly
room and not escape into the auditorium or assembly room.



(1982 Code, § 130.05)  (Ord. 20-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
90.99



§ 90.64  DISTURBANCES OF THE PEACE.



   (A)   It is declared unlawful for any person to congregate, scuffle,
wrestle, box or to be guilty of any other boisterous or disorderly conduct on
any sidewalk in front of any plate glass window in any building in the city,
or to sit or lean against a window, or to loiter, or sit in or in any manner
to obstruct any public stairway in any business building in the city, or to
sit or loiter on the steps or in the entrance to any building.



   (B)   It shall be and is declared unlawful for any person or persons
to idle or loiter in any public place, park, shed, car, car shop, outhouse,
street, alley, railroad depot or switch house in the city.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to be found begging in the
city or lying or sleeping in, along or on any public street, alley, park or
public place or grounds, or in any stable, outhouse, building, warehouse,
shed, railroad depot or railroad car, or in or about any yard, mill or
factory in the city, without having the permission of the owner or occupant
thereof to sleep or be in that place.



   (D)   Any person who, within the limits of the city, shall
unnecessarily make any loud and unusual noise and clamor, or commit any
unseemly and boisterous conduct, to the disturbance of the peace and quiet of
the city shall be deemed guilty of disorderly and unlawful conduct, and on
conviction thereof shall be fined.



(1982 Code, § 130.06)  (Ord. 71-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
90.99



§ 90.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   (1)   If a citation is issued, whoever violates any
provision of §§ 90.20 through 90.29 shall be subject to a civil penalty of
$100.



      (2)   For violations of §§ 90.20 through 90.29, a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or
continues.



(Ord. 13-1999, passed 8-24-1999; Am. Ord. 20-2006, passed 6-27-2006)



   (B)   Every person, firm, corporation, partnership, or sole
proprietorship who violates any provision of § 90.30 shall be subject to a
civil penalty of $250 for the first offense and $500 for the second and all
subsequent offenses.



(Ord. 13-1999, passed 8-24-1999; Am. Ord. 13-1999, passed 8-24-1999; Am. Ord.
20-2006, passed 6-27-2006)



   (C)   (1) Whoever violates any provision of this §§ 90.40 through
90.45 shall be subject to a civil penalty of $250 for the first violation
thereof, and $500 for the second and all subsequent violations. A separate
violation shall be deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or
continues.



      (2)   Any person violating the provisions of this chapter
shall be issued a citation by a city police officer setting forth the
violation committed, the date, time and location of the violation, and inform
the violator that he or she has 10 days after being issued the citation to
pay the penalty at the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer, or the violator
will summoned into court.



(Ord. 9-1984, passed 11-13-1984; Am. Ord. 5-2002, passed 6-11-2002)



   (D)   (1)   Guns/weapons. Whoever violates any provision of §
90.60 shall be fined not less than $1 nor more than $10.



(1982 Code, § 130.99(B))  (Ord. 16-1931 passed 9-22-1931)



      (2)   False alarms. Whoever violates any provision of § 90.61
shall be fined not less than $1 nor more than $25.



(1982 Code, § 130.99(C))  (Ord. 12-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



      (3)   Assemblies. Whoever violates any provision of § 90.63
shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $100.



(1982 Code, § 130.99(D))  (Ord. 20-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



      (4)   Disturbing of peace. Whoever violates any provision of
§ 90.64 shall be fined not more than $10.



(1982 Code, § 130.99(E))  (Ord. 71-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



   (E)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed, shall be subject to § 10.99.



(Ord. 20-2006, passed 6-27-2006)



CHAPTER 91: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
