ADMINISTRATION OF FACILITIES




§ 97.01  AUTHORITY TO OPERATE.



   The city may establish, aid, maintain and operate public parks,
playgrounds and recreation facilities and programs.



§ 97.02  DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION.



   (A)   The Brazil Department of Parks and Recreation shall have
administrative and management jurisdiction over Forest Park, Babe Wheeler
Park and George N. Craig Park.



   (B)   The Department shall consist of a Parks and Recreation Board,
a Park Superintendent and other personnel that the Board deems necessary.



(Ord. 4-1992, passed 5-10-1992)



§ 97.03  FOUR-MEMBER PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD.



   (A)   The Parks and Recreation Board shall consist of 4 members
appointed by the Mayor with no more than 2 being affiliated with the same
political party.



   (B)   The terms of office and the filling of vacancies shall be
according to applicable state statutes.



(Ord. 4-1992, passed 5-10-1992)



§ 97.04  POWERS OF THE BOARD AND PARK SUPERINTENDENT.



   The powers and duties of the members of the Parks and Recreation Board
and the Park Superintendent shall be pursuant to I.C. 36-10-3-1 through
36-10-3-14 and other applicable provisions of this code.



(Ord. 4-1992, passed 5-10-1992)



§ 97.05  DESIGNATION OF 3 CITY PARKS AND OTHER RECREATIONAL AREAS.



   (A)   The City of Brazil, under the jurisdiction of the Department
of Parks and Recreation, operates the following city parks:



      (1)   Babe Wheeler Park;



      (2)   Forest Park (formerly Hendrix Park); and



      (3)   George N. Craig Park



   (B)   There are established the following designated tracts or areas
as and for public playgrounds and recreation centers under and by virtue of
Chapter 1742 of the Acts of 1925, as amended:



      (1)   The tract or parcel of land adjacent to and south of
Forest Park proper which was acquired from the school city and on which is
situated playground equipment, the swimming pool, the bathing beach, the bath
house, the athletic field stadium and the camping or picnic area;



      (2)   The tract or parcel of land adjacent to and southeast of
Forest Park proper, and to the east of and adjacent to the last above
designated tract, acquired from Fred Nichols, and on which is situated that
certain playing field used and maintained as and for a municipal golf course;



      (3)   That tract or parcel of land situated at the southwest
intersection of North Meridian Street  and West Hendrix Street, acquired
from diverse persons, and commonly known as Hendrix Park;



      (4)   The tract or parcel of land situated within the lands
owned by Harry Bradshaw, located north of Hendrix Street and east of State
Highway No. 59, under lease by the city, from year to year; and



      (5)   The area located in the southwest corner of Forest Park
proper on which is situated certain games and playing courts and similar
layouts.



   (C)   All structures, buildings and other improvements situated on
the above designated tracts, parcels or areas are permitted to be used for
playground or recreational purposes pursuant to the provisions of and for the
purposes designated in this section.



(1982 Code, § 94.01)  (Ord. 10-1949, passed 8-2-1949; Am Ord. 35-1983,
passed - -)



§ 97.06  CREATION OF SKATE PARK FUND.



   (A)   There is hereby created a new fund as a part of Brazil Parks
and Recreation Department Non-Reverting Fund which shall be designated as the
"Skate Park Fund."



   (B)   The purpose of the fund is to allow the Brazil Skate Park
Advisory Board to receive monetary donations from the community and
individuals, deposit contributions into the Skate Park Fund and disburse
monies therefrom to construct and maintain for the citizens and youth of
Brazil and Clay County a skate park in Craig Park.



   (C)   The fund shall be perpetual until terminated pursuant to the
terms of this section.



   (D)   This fund may be terminated by the enactment of an ordinance
and any fund balance in that fund shall revert to the Brazil Parks &
Recreation Department Non-Reverting Fund to be used for any purposes lawfully
allowed.



(Ord. 22-2005, passed 8-10-2005)



§ 97.07  SKATE PARK ADVISORY BOARD.



   (A)   There is hereby created and established a Skate Park Advisory
Board under the direction of the Brazil City Park and Recreation Board for
the City of Brazil which shall consist of 5 members, citizens and residents
of Clay County, Indiana, 4 of whom 2 shall be appointed by the Mayor and 2
shall be appointed by the Brazil City Parks and Recreation Board. The Brazil
Human Resources/Safety Director shall be the remaining member of the Skate
Park Advisory Board.



   (B)   The term of the 4 persons shall be 2 years except that the
term of 1 of the members appointed by the Mayor and 1 of the members
appointed by the Brazil Parks and Recreation Board to the first board shall
be for only 1 year and the term of 2 members of the first board shall be for
2 years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any
member, his or her successor shall be appointed by the respective appointing
party for the unexpired portion of the term.



   (C)   Members of the Board shall serve without compensation.



   (D)   It shall be the responsibility of the City Skate Park Advisory
Board to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update, and
administer a written plan for the construction, care and maintenance of the
Skate Park to be built in George Craig Park. A plan will be presented to the
Brazil Parks and Recreation Board and upon their acceptance and approval
shall constitute the official comprehensive construction and maintenance plan
for the skate park. The plan may be updated periodically and an updated plan
will be affective upon approval by the Brazil City Parks and Recreation Board.



   (E)   The City Skate Park Advisory Board shall serve as an advisory
council to the Brazil Parks and Recreation Board concerning the construction,
care and maintenance of the skate park. However, authority and control over
city parks shall remain with the Brazil Parks and Recreation Board. The City
Skate Park Advisory Board shall receive monetary donations from the community
and individuals, and deposit all monetary contributions into the Skate Park
Fund. Furthermore, the City Skate Park Advisory Board shall have the
authority to disburse monies therefrom to construct and maintain for the
citizens and youth of Brazil and Clay County, a skate park in George Craig
Park.



   (F)   The City Skate Park Advisory Board shall choose its own
officers, make its own rules and regulations, and keep minutes of its
proceedings which will form permanent records on file in the City
Clerk-Treasurer's office. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the
transaction of business.



   (G)   The Brazil City Parks and Recreation Board shall have the
right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the City Skate Park
Advisory Board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the City
Skate Park Advisory Board to the City Parks and Recreation Board who may hear
the matter and make final decisions.



(Ord. 23-2005, passed 8-10-2005)




PARK RULES AND REGULATIONS




§ 97.20  AUTHORITY TO ADOPT RULES AND REGULATIONS BY THE BOARD.



   (A)   The Parks and Recreation Board shall adopt and establish rules
and regulations for the control, maintenance, use and regulation of
playground and recreation facilities, bathing areas, swimming and wading
pools and other park and recreation property; for providing and maintaining
all necessary equipment, supplies, building structures and all other property
under its control and jurisdiction; for establishing standards and
qualifications for the appointment of personnel.



   (B)   All promulgated rules and regulations are subject to the
approval by the Mayor before becoming effective.



   (C)   The Board may by the rules and regulations provide for,
regulate, set aside and allocate the use by persons, vehicles and animals of
the public parks, playgrounds and other public places under its control, but
without being limited to classifications, for and into the following general
classes or uses and purposes:



      (1)   Playground areas, including all sports and recreation
activities, bathing areas, swimming and wading pools, other bodies of water
and beaches, athletic fields, child recreation and playground areas; and
uses, with all buildings and structures and equipment appurtenant thereto;



      (2)   Picnic areas, including roadside and park tables,
shelter houses and outdoor ovens for eating and drinking;



      (3)   Public meeting areas, including grandstand areas, music
buildings and exhibition pavilion, use of which may be obtained after
receiving permission from the Board with restrictions on the use of
loudspeakers and other sound amplification devices; and



      (4)   Areas for concerts, amusement attractions and theatrical
performances.



   (D)   The Board is authorized and empowered to restrict or set aside
all various areas of the city's parks, including the entire parks, on
specified and reasonable limited occasions or periods of time for concerts,
carnivals and other amusement attractions and theatrical performances or for
some other special purpose, and may prohibit the use of any or all areas by
other persons at any times, except for the use thereof which is prescribed
and then allowed for any like area.



   (E)   No person of the opposite sex, except children under the age
of 4 years when accompanied by an adult, shall enter a facility provided for
the opposite sex.



(1982 Code, § 30.18)  (Ord. 35-1983, passed 11-28-1983)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.21  PARK HOURS.



   (A)   During the season, when so declared by the Board of Parks and
Recreation, the public parks shall be open to the public during hours
specified by the Board. However, on special occasions and certain sponsored
events, the hours may be changed and fixed generally different from those
specified hours.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an employee of
the city in the course of his or her employment, or except while traveling on
an established highway through a park, to be or remain in any park during any
time it is not open, or to use any park at any time for any unlawful meetings
or purposes.



(1982 Code, § 94.26)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.22  UNLAWFUL TO DAMAGE OR DESTROY PARK/CITY PROPERTY.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to write on, cut,
mutilate, deface, damage, remove or destroy in any manner any building,
swimming or wading pool, golf course, equipment, structure, fountain, fence,
bench, masonry, statue, ornament or any other property, real or personal, or
any appurtenance thereto, owned or operated by the city or its Board of Parks
and Recreation, and located on or in any park, golf course, playground or any
other place or property under the control of the Board.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful to damage or destroy any property leased
or loaned to or by the Board, including any property on which a concession
has been granted by the Boards, or belonging to any person and rightfully an
park property.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful to remove, relocate, damage or destroy
any benches, seats, tables, equipment or other movable property, at any time
from their places in any park, golf course or other park property, without
permission from the Park Superintendent, Golf Course Manager or other
authorized park official.



(1982 Code, § 94.27)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.23  INJURY TO PLANTS AND TREES PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an employee of the Board
of Parks and Recreation or who is not authorized to do so by the Board, to
pull, pluck, break, plant, trample, climb into, injure, mutilate, remove or
destroy any tree, shrub, plant, vine, hedge, flower or fruit, whether wild or
cultivated, or to cut, break down, bend, damage the bark, or trim any
sapling, tree, shrub or plant, or any limbs, branches, twigs or leaves
thereof, that is growing and located in any public park, street, tree row or
playground, or any property controlled, leased or loaned to others by the
Board or on concession has been granted by it, or on any other property
outside a park and which is under the control or supervision of the Board.



(1982 Code, § 94.28)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.24  PROHIBITED CONDUCT.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to use profane, obscene,
lewd, threatening or abusive language; or to fight, quarrel or throw any
stone or missile; or to behave in a loud or disorderly manner; or to commit
any offense against decency, good morals or contrary to law; or to litter,
dump or deposit any garbage or other offensive substance or article on any
park, playground or any other property under the control or supervision of
the Board of Parks and Recreation, or on any property leased or loaned or on
which a concession has been granted by it; or to use or participate with
others in using any places for any subversive, seditious or other unlawful
purposes.



   (B)   No unlawful, threatening, abusive, profane, lewd or indecent
language, gesture or conduct shall be permitted in, or in the vicinity of any
bathing beach, wading or swimming pool, recreation center or playground, nor
shall any person who is lawfully at any place be so annoyed or unlawfully
touched.



(1982 Code, § 94.29)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.25  GAMBLING AND SOLICITING RESTRICTED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to gamble or violate any federal,
state or city laws pertaining thereto, or to beg, hawk, peddle, distribute or
solicit or offer for sale any article, thing, paper, privilege or service
within the parks, nor circulate petitions within the parks without permission
from the Board of Parks and Recreation.



(1982 Code, § 94.30)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.26  DISCHARGING FIREARMS AND POSSESSION OF WEAPONS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by the Board of
Parks and Recreation, to discharge any firearms or have possession of any
firearms or other explosive devices, or to endanger others by the use of any
weapon, article or device within any park, playground or on any property
controlled or leased by the Board of Parks and Recreation, or on which a
concession has been granted by it.



(1982 Code, § 94.31)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.27  ALCOHOL AND DRUGS PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to be intoxicated or under the
influence or effect of narcotics, or to use alcohol or narcotics in any park,
playground, community building, golf clubhouse, swimming or wading pool or
beach, or other premises or places under the jurisdiction or control of the
Board of Parks and Recreation without the permission of the Board.



(1982 Code, § 94.32)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.28  ORGANIZED PICNICS; USE OF OUTDOOR OVENS.



   (A)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not
invited or included by the sponsors thereof to intrude himself or herself on
a picnic without the consent of those in charge thereof, or to disturb any
picnic within the parks.



      (2)   The Board shall adopt general rules and regulations as
necessary for compelling persons holding picnics or eating anything within
any public park to clean up the ground and remove or dispose of all food,
paper, litter and other debris before leaving the premises.



(1982 Code, § 94.33)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, not an employee of the
Board of Parks and Recreation, to build, kindle or ignite a fire for cooking,
heating or any other purpose in any park, playground or on any property
controlled or leased by the Board, or on which a concession has been granted
by it, or on any other property under the control or supervision of the Board
of Parks and Recreation, except as allowed for any purposes in accordance
with regulations as the Board shall establish regulating the use of outdoor
ovens at any designated places or other uses in certain areas.



(1982 Code, § 94.34)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.29  ADVERTISING AND SALES RESTRICTED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to paint, post or
otherwise affix any bill, notice or advertising sign on any structure, tree
or thing within any park, playground, golf course or other property under the
control of the Board of Parks and Recreation, without having obtained
permission therefor from the Board of Parks and Recreation.



(1982 Code, § 94.35)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale or
barter any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind whatever within any public
park, playground or other park property, without having first obtained
consent or a concession therefor from the Board of Parks and Recreation.



(1982 Code, § 94.36)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.30  DANGEROUS SPORTS AND ACTIVITIES.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive golf balls, fly model
planes, throw objects, practice archery or shooting or participate in any
other games or activities which are hazardous to others on property
controlled or operated by the Board of Parks and Recreation, or located in or
on any park or playground, however, the Board of Parks and Recreation may set
aside and designate places and specify the times and regulations for engaging
in any like activities. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or
operate a skateboard on, in, or upon any portion of the "pavilion building"
or the "band shell building" located in Forest Park, which is a municipal
park located in the City of Brazil, Indiana.



(Ord. 18-2004, passed 8-10-2004)  Penalty, see § 94.99.



§ 97.31  HARMING OR ENDANGERING WILDLIFE AND ANIMALS PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, being the owner of or
having control thereof, and without permission of the Board of Parks and
Recreation, to suffer or permit any animals or fowl to stray into or to run
at large or unattended or to trespass on any park, playground, waters or any
property controlled, leased or loaned by the Board of Parks and Recreation or
on which a concession has been granted by it.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person harboring or controlling a
dog to permit or to suffer a dog, when not attended and under control of the
person and held by a leash, to be in any park, public playground or golf
course, or at any time to enter any wading or swimming pool or beach located
therein.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, lead or drive a
horse, mule, pony, donkey or any other beast of burden on any park property,
except that the Board of Parks and Recreation may designate certain portions
of park property as bridle paths or other areas wherein horses and other
equine animals may be ridden. Horseback and other animal riding shall be
confined exclusively to designated bridle paths and in public parks, or to
other places set apart for that use. Reckless riding or racing at any place
shall be unlawful. Riding horses or other animals on or across grass, lawns,
flower beds, golf courses or any park property, other than on bridle paths or
places designated therefor, shall be unlawful.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person, not an employee of the
Board of Parks and Recreation or not authorized by the Board, to chase,
catch, trap, injure, molest, kill, disturb, annoy or remove any animal, bird,
fish, reptile or fowl, either wild or domestic, on land, in the air or water
or in any place in the parks, zoo or playground or any property controlled,
leased or loaned by the Board, or on which a concession has been granted by
it.



(1982 Code, § 94.38)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)  Penalty, see §
97.99



§ 97.32  VEHICULAR TRAFFIC.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, excepting police
officers, firefighters and emergency vehicle drivers, to drive or propel or
cause to be driven or propelled along or over any road within the parks, any
vehicle at a greater speed than 15 mph, unless otherwise posted.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to:



      (1)   Drive any vehicle on any area except the park roadways
or parking areas or other areas as may on occasion be specifically designated
as temporary parking areas by the Board of Parks and Recreation or the Board
of Public Works and Safety;



      (2)   Drive any vehicle on foot paths, pedestrian walks,
nature trails and bridle paths designated and established for pedestrian
travel and horseback riding;



      (3)   Park a vehicle on a roadway or parking area in a manner
or under conditions so as to impede or obstruct the normal and safe flow of
traffic;



      (4)   Operate a motor vehicle in the park without the use of a
muffler adequate to deaden the sound of the engine in the vehicle;



      (5)   Operate a vehicle in the parks which emits excessive
noxious fumes or dense smoke;



      (6)   Use a siren or other type of loud sounding device which
makes unusually loud and unnecessary noise, excepting persons driving police,
fire or emergency vehicles;



      (7)   Operate a motor vehicle on a service drive except in
making deliveries and servicing the facility to which the without permission
of the Park Superintendent or Board of Parks and Recreation;



      (8)   Park a vehicle within the boundaries of Forest Park at
the northeast corner of Roy Brann Stadium beginning at the east edge of the
crosswalk at the intersection of Miller Drive and South Nabuco Drive
extending westerly a distance of 50 feet; and on the south side of Miller
Drive beginning 158 feet  from the southwest corner of the intersection of
Miller Drive and South Nabuco Drive and extending northerly a distance of 30
feet (to be designated as an "Ambulance Entrance") during the hours when the
swimming pool is open to the public;



      (9)   Park or otherwise stop a vehicle within the boundaries
of Forest Park on the south side of Miller Drive in front of the swimming
pool entrance, beginning 102 feet from the southwest corner of the
intersection of Miller Drive and South Nabuco Drive and extending northerly a
distance of 30 feet only during the hours when the swimming pool is open to
the public, unless the vehicle shall have attached thereto a disabled license
plate or other conspicuous evidence that it is being used to transport a
disabled. That  area shall be designated as “Disabled Parking Only When
Pool Open;” or



      (10)   Operate a vehicle through the following intersections
within the boundaries of and at Forest Park located within the corporate
limits of the city without first coming to a complete stop: King Avenue at
the intersection with East Pinkley Street; King Avenue at the intersection
with East Deloss Street; Miller Drive at the intersection with King Avenue;
Ivan Fuqua Drive at the intersection with King Avenue; South Nabuco Drive at
the intersection with South Forest Avenue; Miller Drive at the intersection
with the Cabin Crosswalk; Miller Drive at the intersection with South Nabuco
Drive; Stadium Drive at the intersection with South Nabuco Drive; East Nabuco
Drive at the Intersection with South Nabuco Drive; East Nabuco Drive at the
Intersection with East Pinkley Street.



   (C)   As used in this section, the term VEHICLE shall mean any motor
vehicle, automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer, semi-trailer, truck tractor,
bus, school bus, recreational vehicle, construction vehicle, tractor and
bicycle.



(1982 Code, § 94.39)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978; Am. Ord. 28-1983,
passed - -)  Penalty, see § 97.99



§ 97.33  PARK AND RECREATION FEES.



   (A)   Pool hours are 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m. with a review after the
first months to see if lengthening the hours is warranted.



   (B)   A flat fee of $80 will be charged with lifeguard fees being
paid by the party givers. The number of lifeguards needed would depend on the
size of the party. Party guidelines will govern.



   (C)   Admission fees and passes:



      (1)   Daily rates:



         (a)   Ages 0–4: Free when accompanied by a paying
adult;



         (b)   Ages 5–9: $2.00;



         (c)   Ages 10–16: $2.25;



         (d)   Ages 17+: $2.50; and



         (e)   Ages 60+: $1.50.



      (2)   Passes:



         (a)   Ages 5–9: $50.00;



         (b)   Ages 10–16: $55.00;



         (c)   Ages 17+: $60.00; and



         (d)   Ages 60+: $50.00.



      (3)   Family passes (up to 4 members):



         (a)   Clay County resident: $100.00;



         (b)   Non-county resident $125.00; and



         (c)   $10.00 each additional family member.



      (4)   A block of 30 daily admission tickets will be discounted
20% if paid in advance.



   (D)   The park shelter may be reserved at a fee based on the number
of people with a minimum fee amount of $20.00.



   (E)   The Park Manager and all related personnel will be paid at
rates established by the Board of Parks and Recreation.



(Board of Parks and Recreation Meeting of March 19, 1998)




MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE OPERATIONS




§ 97.45  PURPOSE; AUTHORITY TO OPERATE.



   (A)   It is deemed necessary and proper that it is in the best
interests of the city, the public and golfing enthusiasts who utilized the
municipal golf course of the city, that a board be created and given the
authority to control, supervise and operate specifically and exclusively the
golf course because of its particular and special nature; that members of the
newly created board be especially sensitive to and knowledgeable of the
particular needs of the golf course and the desires of those citizens who
utilize and enjoy the sport of golfing at the golf course and that those
persons who consistently utilize the golf course facility be allowed to
provide their input into the operation, maintenance, improvement and
expansion of the golf course.



(1982 Code, § 94.10)  (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)



   (B)   The city has the power to acquire, develop, improve and
operate golf courses, either as a part of or in connection with its public
park, or separate and apart therefrom, pursuant to I.C. 36-10-5-3(b).



(1982 Code, § 94.11)  (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)



§ 97.46  CREATION OF MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE BOARD; COMPENSATION AND TERMS OF
OFFICE.



   (A)   There is created the City Municipal Golf Course Board which
shall have the power to govern, control, supervise, operate and acquire
property for purposes of the golf course previously vested in the Board of
Parks and Recreation.



(1982 Code, § 94.12)  (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)



   (B)   (1)   The Golf Course Board shall consist of 5 members
appointed by the Mayor, all of whom must be residents of Clay County, Indiana
for at least 5 years, and have, in the opinion of the Mayor, actively
participated in the sport of golf in Clay County, shown an interest in the
operation of the golf course facility, the ability to make decisions
concerning the operation and maintenance of the golf course.



      (2)   The first members of the Golf Course Board shall hold
office respectively as follows: one for a term of 1 year; 1 for a term of 2
years; 1 for a term of 3 years; and 2 for a term of 4 years. The Mayor shall
appoint a new member to fill each of the vacancies caused by the expiration
of the above respective terms, and newly-appointed members shall hold office
for a term of 4 years.



      (3)   If a vacancy occurs in the membership of the Board, by
resignation or otherwise, the Mayor shall appoint a replacement for the
residue of the departing member's term.



      (4)   The Board members serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and
may be removed only for cause, upon specific written filed against them.



         (a)   The charges shall be filed and heard by the Mayor
unless the Mayor brings the charges. If the Mayor brings the charges, the
Common Council shall meet and appoint a person to serve as hearing officer to
hear the particular charges against the accused Board member who is not
related to the accused member or the Mayor nor a salaried employee of the
city.



         (b)   The hearing officer shall fix a date for a public
hearing and give notice to the accused member at least 10 days in advance of
the hearing.



         (c)   At the hearing, the member shall be entitled to
present evidence and argument on his or her behalf, be represented by legal
counsel and cross-examine opposing witnesses.



         (d)   Following the submission of all evidence and
argument, the hearing officer shall consider same and make special findings
of fact and determination of the member's guilt or innocence of the alleged
charges.



(Am. Ord. 9-1982, passed 6-28-1982)



         (e)   The members shall serve without compensation
except for actual expenses to be approved by the Mayor and the Common Council.



(1982 Code, § 94.13)  (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)



§ 97.47  POWERS AND DUTIES OF BOARD.



   (A)   The Golf Course Board shall have the power to develop, improve
and operate the golf course, acquire the already existing golf course and
lands developed for that purpose, and issue municipal bonds to pay the cost
of any acquisition, development and improvement, or for any of the purposes,
subject to statutes relating to the issuance of bonds and the making of
appropriations by the city.



   (B)   In addition to the above powers, the Board shall have the
following powers and duties:



      (1)   Exercise general supervision of and control over the
operation, maintenance, development and improvement of the golf course;



      (2)   Make rules and regulations governing the operation,
maintenance and use of the golf course facilities;



      (3)   Hire necessary professional, managerial and maintenance
staff personnel and employees for the efficient operation and maintenance of
the golf course without regard to political affiliation, plus discipline and
dismiss any personnel and employees for cause;



      (4)   Make necessary contracts and leases for facilities,
services and equipment necessary for the proper operation of the golf course;



      (5)   Contract with not-for-profit corporations or
organizations for use of the golf course facilities for teaching purposes,
youth athletic programs, tournaments and other related services;



      (6)   Acquire and dispose of real and personal property
related to the golf course or needed for the efficient operation, improvement
or expansion of the golf course;



      (7)   Exercise the power of eminent domain under the authority
of any laws generally made available to municipalities for this purpose;



      (8)   Establish standards and qualifications for the
appointment and hire of all personnel, fix their compensation and determine
causes for disciplinary action or dismissal of employees;



      (9)   Contract for special and temporary services and for
professional assistance;



      (10)   Make recommendations and an annual report to the Mayor
and the Common Council concerning the operation of the Board and the golf
course;



      (11)   Invoke any legal, equitable or special remedy for the
enforcement of the provisions of any ordinance relating to the use and
operation of the golf course or any other applicable ordinance or law;



      (12)   Prepare and submit an annual budget in the same manner
as other departments of the city as prescribed by the State Board of Accounts;



      (13)   Authorize and regulate the operation of a golf pro shop
including the sale of golf-related equipment and apparel; and



      (14)   Fix the fees and rates to be charged for the playing of
golf on the golf course and for tournament authorized and held thereon.



(1982 Code, § 94.14)  (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)



§ 97.48  MEETINGS; TRANSFER OF POWERS.



   (A)   (1)   Meetings of the Board shall be public. The Board
shall fix the time and place of its meetings, but it shall meet at least
quarterly.



      (2)   These meeting shall be called by the President of the
Board on his or her own request or the request of any member. Written notice
of the meeting shall be sent to all members by the Secretary of the Board at
least 48 hours in advance of the meeting.



      (3)   All regularly scheduled and special meetings of the
Board shall comply with the Indiana Open Door Law, I.C. 5-14-1.5-1 through
5-14-1.5-7.



      (4)   A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum and
any action of the Board is not official unless authorized by at least 3
members present and acting.



(1982 Code, § 94.15)  (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)



   (B)   In addition to powers and duties specified in § 97.47, the
powers and duties previously vested in the Board of Parks and Recreation
pertaining to the golf course are transferred to the Golf Course Board.



(1982 Code, § 94.16)  (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)



§ 97.49  GOLF COURSE REGULATIONS.



   (A)   Except during the hours specified, no person other than
employees of the golf course shall be permitted to remain in the golf
clubhouse on any part of the course. No person shall play golf on the links
except on payment of the fees stipulated by it and in compliance with its
rules and regulations thereon, as may be adopted by it at any time.



   (B)   All persons within the limits of the golf course must at all
times abide by the rules and, regulations of the golf course, which shall be
posted in the clubhouse or on the course, and by the orders of the custodian
of the course, and shall not violate any laws of the city or state. For any
violation of this, the violator may be punished as prescribed by this code
and be excluded from the use of the golf course.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale
golf balls, clubs or any articles for whatever use in playing golf on the
municipal golf course within 500 feet of the boundary line of the golf
course, without written consent of the Board.



(1982 Code, § 94.40)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)



§ 97.50  ENFORCEMENT.



   The Board of Parks and Recreation, Park Superintendent, recreation
supervisors, Golf Course Manager, park police, police of the city and of the
state, all health authorities and other employees of the Board of Parks and
Recreation holding special police powers are authorized and empowered to
enforce any and all of the provisions of this chapter and laws of the state
and city in all places under the control of the Board of Parks and Recreation
and the Board of Public Works and Safety.



(1982 Code, § 94.41)  (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)



§ 97.99  PENALTY.



   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no penalty is
otherwise provided, shall be fined $50. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues.



(Ord. 18-2004, passed 8-10-2004)



CHAPTER 98:  CEMETERIES



Section



   98.01   Common Council to oversee cemeteries



   98.02   Three city-owned cemeteries



   98.03   Officers and office overseeing city-owned cemeteries



   98.04   Rules for cemetery lot owners



   98.05   Opening and closing of graves; fees



   98.06   Purchase of burial plots



   98.07   Removals; fees



   98.08   Rules



   98.09   Undertakers



   98.10   Monumental work



   98.11   Decorations



   98.12   General management



   98.99   Penalty



§ 98.01  COMMON COUNCIL TO OVERSEE CEMETERIES.



   The city-owned cemeteries shall be controlled and managed by the Common
Council pursuant to I.C. 3-14-24-1 et seq. and applicable city ordinances and
other state statutes.



(1982 Code, § 30.04)  (Ord. 14-1982, passed 8-30-1982)



§ 98.02  THREE CITY-OWNED CEMETERIES.



   The City of Brazil manages and controls the following cemeteries:



   (A)   Cottage Hill;



   (B)   Old Hill; and



   (C)   Restlawn.



§ 98.03  OFFICERS AND OFFICE OVERSEEING CITY-OWNED CEMETERIES.



   (A)   The Supervisor of the city-owned and maintained cemeteries and
employed assistants shall be designated "the officers" and shall have the
responsibility of giving their constant and personal attention to the care,
maintenance, operation and management of the cemeteries.



   (B)   The office of the Supervisor is located at the Cottage Hill
Cemetery at the right driveway near the entrance. All the lot and grave
owners in the cemeteries should consult with the officers at all times.
Advice and assistance will be given without charge to those contemplating the
purchases of monuments or the making of other improvements.



   (C)   Orders for work, complaints and lost and found articles should
be reported at the office of the Supervisor or the City Clerk-Treasurer. All
business involving the cemeteries will be transacted at these offices.



   (D)   Employees of the cemeteries are prohibited from accepting
orders or instructions for work from anyone except the Supervisor. Every
person is requested to report to the Supervisor any errors or lack of proper
care in the execution of duties of the cemetery employees.



   (E)   No tips, gratuities or fees are permitted to be paid to
cemetery employees by any person.



(1982 Code, § 91.01)  (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)



§ 98.04  RULES FOR CEMETERY LOT OWNERS.



   (A)   All deeds to cemetery lot owners when executed shall be
construed as simply granting the purchaser of the lot conveyed the right to
use the lot for the interment of himself or herself, his or her family,
relatives and decedents.



   (B)   Cemetery lot owners shall not be permitted to transfer their
right to any unused portion of a lot except by written permit signed and
approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety, the City Clerk-Treasurer
and the Supervisor of the cemeteries.



(1982 Code, § 91.02)  (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.05  OPENING AND CLOSING OF GRAVES; FEES.



   (A)   All lot owners are to bring their deed or proof of right of
burial when ordering graves opened.



   (B)   All orders for opening graves must be made at least 16 hours
before the time set for the funeral.



   (C)   When a new grave is opened in close proximity to a previous
interment, it is often impossible to avoid damaging the old grave. The
management or the city will not be responsible for that damage and remounding
or reboxing. If ordered, fees will be charged to the lot owner of the opened
grave.



   (D)   In the case of death from smallpox, or cholera, the grave will
be prepared by the cemetery employees, but neither they nor the Supervisor
will be present at the interment. The Board of Health must furnish the tools
and employees to handle the remains and close the grave.



(1982 Code, § 91.03(A)-(D))



   (E)   Price for opening and closing graves shall be as follows:



      (1)   All graves under 4 feet in length-$125;



      (2)   All other graves-$400; and



      (3)   Ash burial-$125.



(Ord. 4-2004, passed 2-23-2004)



   (F)   All improvement work on burial lots such as resurfacing,
grading, excavating, sodding, setting trees, placing foundation work for
stone work or setting corner posts must be done by cemetery employees under
the supervision of the Supervisor.



(1982 Code, § 91.03(F))  (Am. Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-23-1981)



§ 98.06  PURCHASE OF BURIAL PLOTS.



   (A)   Persons desiring to purchase burial plots will, on application
therefor at the cemetery office, be accompanied over the cemetery grounds by
the Supervisor who will assist them in selecting a plot.



   (B)   Having decided on a suitable location for the grave plot, the
purchaser shall return to the office where he or she will be given an
application form properly filled out, describing the lot, section, number and
price. Upon presenting the completed application form at the
Clerk-Treasurer's office in the city building, and payment to the
Clerk-Treasurer the consideration for the plot, the Clerk-Treasurer shall
execute a deed to the purchaser.



   (C)   No interment will be allowed until payment of the full
purchase price for the lot on which the interment is to be made.



(1982 Code, § 91.04(C))  (Am. Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-23-1981)



   (D)   Prices of burial plots shall be as follows:



      (1)   Single grave (adult)-$250; and



      (2)   Single grave (children)-$125.



(Ord. 4-1994, passed 4-12-1994)



§ 98.07  REMOVALS; FEES.



   (A)   Under no condition shall a removal of a body from a grave be
made where death was caused by smallpox or cholera.



   (B)   The price of removal of a body from a grave shall be $150.



   (C)   In making removals from 1 cemetery to another, the price shall
be governed by the distance, condition of the remains and time and labor
required.



   (D)   Burial plots may be surrendered only after they have been
cleared of all encumbrances and when recommended by the Supervisor.



(1982 Code, § 91.05)  (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.08  RULES.



   (A)   The proper burial certificate required by the municipal
authorities must be delivered at the gate office before any interment is
made, or anyone is placed in any vault or tomb.



   (B)   All persons are prohibited from driving a horse-drawn or
motor-driven conveyance through the grounds faster than 10 mph.



   (C)   Bicycle or sled riding in all cemeteries is prohibited.



   (D)   No person shall park a car within 50 feet of an open grave.



   (E)   All motor vehicles shall be stopped and the motor shut off
within 50 feet of any burial service in progress.



   (F)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or company to
advertise any business or product in or on any cemetery, except by permission
of the Supervisor.



   (G)   All persons are prohibited from plucking flowers, whether wild
or cultivated.



   (H)   Taking pictures is prohibited in the cemetery, except by
permission of the Supervisor.



   (I)   Children under 10 years of age shall be accompanied by parents
or guardian who will be responsible for their conduct while in the cemetery.



   (J)   Writing on or otherwise defacing any mausoleum, monument,
marker or memorial structure of any kind is prohibited.



   (K)   All persons are prohibited from discharging firearms in the
cemetery except in case of military funerals or by special permission of the
Supervisor.



   (L)   No visitors or curiosity seekers are permitted to be present
at the removal of a body.



(1982 Code, § 91.06)  (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.09  UNDERTAKERS.



   (A)   Undertakers are requested to make complete arrangements with
the Supervisor so no confusion will result in burials at the same hour.



   (B)   All undertakers are urgently requested by the management to so
arrange funerals as to give the cemetery employees ample time to prepare and
close the grave during the regular working hours of the employees. An extra
charge will be made when employees are held overtime to complete the
services. The regular working hours of the employees are from 7:00 a.m. to
3:30 p.m.



   (C)   All funeral processions while within the grounds will be
subject to the control of the Supervisor and his or her assistants. Every
possible effort will be made by the Supervisor and cemetery employees to
prevent any inconvenience to funeral processions while within the cemetery.
It is often necessary to prohibit parking on certain driveways, and every
person shall obey the signs or signals at the intersections.



   (D)   Any person observed parking on the lawn will be subject to
arrest for malicious trespass.



   (E)   Driving a car backwards, or making a complete turn on any
drive or avenue in the cemetery is prohibited.



   (F)   The sale of refreshments, merchandise and flowers on cemetery
property is prohibited.



(1982 Code, § 91.07)  (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)



§ 98.10  MONUMENTAL WORK.



   (A)   All workpersons engaged in erecting monuments or other
structures are prohibited from attaching ropes to any tree or shrub except by
permission of the Supervisor.



   (B)   All workpersons and builders are under the control and
direction of the Supervisor while on the grounds and must enter and leave the
cemetery during the working hours of the cemetery employees. Any workperson
failing to comply with this regulation shall not be permitted to work in the
cemetery.



   (C)   No stone work shall be begun on Saturday that cannot be
finished and the debris cleared away before the regular quitting time of the
cemetery employees.



   (D)   No stone work shall be removed from the cemetery except by
permission of the Supervisor.



   (E)   All markers must be placed at the opposite end of the grave
from the monument.



   (F)   The management does not bind itself to maintain or replace any
stone or structure erected on any lot.



(1982 Code, § 91.08)  (Ord. 1-1951, passed 4-10-1951; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)



§ 98.11  DECORATIONS.



   (A)   Toys, cans, dishes, globes, shells, bottles or bric-a-brac of
any kind shall not be allowed on the graves, as they interfere with cutting
the grass. These articles will be promptly removed whenever found.



   (B)   Dead flowers, weeds, grass, paper or other forms of rubbish
shall be put in the containers provided for that purpose, and shall by no
means be piled against trees or left on the section.



   (C)   Planting trees as boundary line marks to prohibited.



   (D)   Fences or enclosures are prohibited on any lot or part.



   (E)   Wooden trellises, vines or shrubs are prohibited on any lot or
grave unless approved by the Supervisor.



   (F)   Lot owners shall not place any chair, settee or portable seat
of any kind on their lot, as they attract strangers to the lot and the
constant use of them destroys the grass and is objectionable in other ways.



   (G)   When trees or shrubs by means of their height or branches,
become detrimental to adjacent lots, or dangerous or inconvenient to
passengers, it shall be the duty of the Supervisor to remove the tree, shrub
or offending part thereof.



   (H)   No grave mounds shall be permitted.



   (I)   All bouquet holders must be set flush with the surface of the
ground. Vases with cut flowers may be placed on graves, but will be removed
when the flowers wither.



   (J)   Unfilled vases and urns shall not be allowed to remain on lots
after July 1 of each year, but will be removed from the lot and held subject
to the order of the lot owner for 1 year after which all responsibility of
the cemetery ceases, and disposal will be made as the management deems best.



   (K)   Floral designs or other decorations will be removed from lots
or graves as soon as the flowers become wilted or unsightly, and persons
wishing to retain the same must remove them within 48 hours after the funeral.



   (L)   Winter decorations, holly, evergreen or artificial wreaths may
be placed on the graves beginning November 1 and may remain until March 1,
after which date all decorations will be removed. If these are to be kept for
future use, they must be removed and cared for by the lot owner before March
1.



   (M)   Seats or benches of stone will not hereafter be permitted in
the cemetery, and as those now existing become broken, or out of repair, they
will be removed and may not be replaced.



   (N)   Before ordering monuments or markers, lot owners must consult
the Supervisor and ascertain if there is space on the lot for the desired
stone or markers.



   (O)   If any trees or shrubs situated on any lot shall, by reason of
the growth of their roots and branches, or in any other way, become
detrimental to the adjacent lots, walks, driveways or avenues, or dangerous
or inconvenient to it shall be the duty of the passers-by, Supervisor to
enter on the lot and remove the trees or shrubs, or parts thereof as are thus
detrimental, dangerous or inconvenient.



(1982 Code, § 91.09)  (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)  Penalty, see § 98.99



§ 98.12  GENERAL MANAGEMENT.



   (A)   All lot and grave owners will be presented with a copy of this
chapter on application at the cemetery office.



   (B)   Questions which may arise, not covered in these rules, are
subject to the decision of the Supervisor, and Board of Public Works and
Safety and the Common Council.



   (C)   Visitors are requested to observe the decorum which should
characterize a place, and unnecessary noise or improper conduct of any person
will not be tolerated.



   (D)   The Supervisor is charged with the execution of these rules
and persons are requested to inform him or her of any breach of these rules
of which they become aware.



   (E)   The Supervisor and his or her deputies are invested with full
police power to arrest any offender in these grounds. They shall expel from
the grounds any violator of these rules or any person disturbing the sanctity
of the place by any act of disrespect whereby the offender is subject to
punishment.



   (F)   The cemetery gates or entrance will be opened at 7:00 a.m. and
closed at sunset.



(1982 Code, § 91.10)  (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)



§ 98.99  PENALTY.



   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
Class B infraction and subject to a penalty of not more than $1,000. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day that a violation
occurs or continues.



(1982 Code, § 91.99)  (Ord. 10-1945, passed 10-28-1945; Am. Ord. 20-1981,
passed 11-23-1981)

GENERAL PROVISIONS




§ 110.01  AUTHORITY TO LICENSE.



   The city has the authority to impose a license fee reasonably related
to the administrative cost of exercising those powers.



§ 110.02  ISSUANCE AND INSPECTIONS.



   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue licenses upon payment of the
license fees and compliance with the applicable provisions of the Brazil City
Code, unless otherwise indicated.



   (B)   The Police Department shall inspect all places of business
under license or required to have a license.



§ 110.03  COMPLAINTS, REVOCATIONS AND SUSPENSIONS.



   (A)   The Mayor shall hear any complaint against a person to whom
the City of Brazil has issued a license.



   (B)   The Mayor make revoke or suspend any license if he or she
finds, after proper notice, and that the person has willfully violated a term
or condition of his or her license, or has willfully done or permitted to be
done an act in violation of a statute or provisions of the Brazil City Code.



   (C)   The Mayor shall file a copy of his or her findings and
determination with the Clerk-Treasurer within 72 hours after it is made.



§ 110.04  SERVICE CHARGE FOR UNHONORED OR RETURNED CHECKS.



   (A)   Purpose. The Brazil city water utility’s tariff approved by
the Public Service Commission of Indiana on September 5, 1984 provided for
the charging of a "bad check charge" by the water utility in the amount of $5
per check to any customer who presents a check on an overdrawn account, on an
account with insufficient funds or deposit or on a closed account for payment
of metered water charges or other water utility charges provided in that
tariff. The purpose of this section is to provide for the charging of a "bad
check charge" as set forth in the tariff and established a procedure for the
enforcement and collection of a charge.



   (B)   Charge for the presentment of bad checks.



      (1)   The Brazil city waterworks shall charge any customer
thereof a "bad check charge" in the sum of $5 per check who presents to the
waterworks office any check on an overdrawn account, with insufficient funds
on deposit, or on a closed account for payment of that customer’s metered
water charge or other water utility charges as provided in that tariff.



      (2)   This section and the "bad check charge" provided for
herein shall be administered and collected by the staff of the supervisor of
the waterworks office either by placing that charge on the customer’s next
water bill, by collecting it at the time the customer resubmits payment of
the overdrawn check or by the utilization of any legal means available for
the collection of bad checks. The supervisor shall establish a procedure.



(Ord. 6-1992, passed 4-14-1992)



§ 110.05  COPYING OR DUPLICATION FEE.



   (A)   Any person requesting a copy of a public record shall pay in
advance to the Clerk-Treasurer of the city, the actual cost of copying the
record which is determined to be $0.25 per page for standard size copies
(8-1/2 x 11 or 8-1/2 x 14) and $0.50 per page for non-standard copies.



   (B)   If the city does not have mechanical means for copying a
requested record, the person requesting the record shall be entitled to
inspect and manually transcribe the record. The city shall not charge to
inspect a public record to determine whether the record may be disclosed.



§ 110.06  ACCIDENT REPORT FEE.



   (A)   The Police Department of the City of Brazil, Indiana, shall
furnish, upon demand, to any person who has sustained any loss or damage, by
reason of injury or death of any person or damage to property caused by or
resulting from the operation, maintenance or use of any vehicle upon any
public street or highway of this state, the information as set forth pursuant
to applicable state law.



   (B)   The Police Department is authorized to charge as a fee for the
information an amount to be determined by the Common Council by resolution,
the amount to be not less than the sum of $3 for each sum report.



   (C)   The fee collected under this section shall be deposited in a
separate account and entitled "Accident," which sums may be expended at the
discretion of the Chief Administrative Officer of the Police Department for
any Department purposes reasonably related to the keeping of accident reports
and records or the prevention of street and highway accidents.



§ 110.07  MOTOR VEHICLE INSPECTION FEE.



   (A)   A fee of $5 for each motor vehicle inspection for purposes of
motor vehicle certificate of title applications.



   (B)   A special vehicle inspection fund is established for the
purpose of depositing all money collected for the motor vehicle inspections.



   (C)   The monies collected shall only be used for law enforcement
purposes for the Brazil Police Department.



(Ord. 15-1988, passed 6-28-1988)



§ 110.08  BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION FEES.



   All building and construction permit fees are set forth in Title XV of
this Brazil City Code.



§ 110.09  PLANNING AND ZONING FEES.



   All planning and zoning fees are set forth in Chapter 157 of this
Brazil City Code.



§ 110.10  UTILITY FEES.



   All utility fees, including but not limited to water and sewage fees
are set forth in Title V of this Brazil City Code.
