§ 110.12  LIMITS ON SALES OF PRODUCTS CONTAINING EPHEDRINE AND THE LIKE.



   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



      CUSTOMER.  Any person who purchases or acquires products from
any retail store.



      EPHEDRINE.  Any drug, substance or compound, whether legal or
illegal, that contains ephedrine, pseudoephedrine, ephedrine hydrochloride,
pseudoephedrine hydrochloride, pseudoephedrine sulfate or phenylpropanolamine.



      PACKAGE.  Any bottle, box, blister pack or other container in
which products containing ephedrine are sold.



      PERMITTEE.  A person who has obtained a permit to sell ephedrine
to customers.



      PERSON.  Any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.



      RETAIL STORE.  Any single geographic location of any business,
company, corporation, person, employee or associate, that sells ephedrine to
any customer. It does not include any wholesalers engaged in a wholesale
transaction.



      SELL.  To furnish, give away, exchange, transfer, deliver,
surrender, distribute or supply, whether or not for monetary gain or other
consideration.



      WHOLESALER.  One whose business is the selling of goods in gross
to retail stores for purposes of resale.



   (B)   Permits. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a
retail store in the City of Brazil that does not possess a valid permit
issued by the Clerk-Treasurer. The permit shall be posted in the
establishment in a place conspicuous to the public.



      (1)   No permit is required for a prescription written by a
licensed physician and/or a pharmacist providing the drugs for a prescription.



      (2)   An applicant may apply for a permit, at no cost, by
submitting a completed application form to the Clerk-Treasurer's office.



      (3)   All permits issued by the Clerk-Treasurer's office shall
contain the name of the retail store; name of the person to whom the permit
is granted; the address of the retail store for which the permit is issued;
and the inclusive dates the permit is valid, if other than for a calendar
year.



      (4)   A permit issued to a retail store shall not be sold,
assigned or transferred.



      (5)   Should any person fail to obtain a permit, the person
shall be charged a $250 penalty.



   (C)   Limitations on the sale or purchase of ephedrine products.



      (1)   Each permittee shall require from its customer
identification showing he or she is of legal age (18), a picture form of
identification and current address. All information obtained on the customer
shall be recorded in an appropriate manner and a copy of the report shall be
forwarded to the Brazil City Police Department at the end of each calendar
month by the permittee.



      (2)   It is unlawful for any person or permittee during a
single transaction to sell to a customer more than 2 packages of products
containing ephedrine.



      (3)   It is unlawful for any customer to purchase or acquire
more than 2 packages of products containing ephedrine within a 7-day period.



   (D)   Exclusions. This section excludes any prescription written by
a licensed physician and a pharmacist providing the drugs for a prescription.



   (E)   Separate violations of each incident. Each offense shall be
considered a separate offense and subject to a fine. Each 24 hours that a
violation occurs will be considered a separate offense and can be cited as so.



   (F)   Penalty. Whoever violates any provision of this section shall
be fined $500. Each day the violation is committed or permitted to continue
shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 6-2005, passed 4-27-2005)




LICENSING




§ 110.25  RESTRICTED HOURS OF BUSINESS FOR PLACES OF SELECTED ENTERTAINMENT.



   All pool rooms, billiard rooms, pool and billiard parlors, bowling
alleys, shooting galleries, public dance halls, skating rinks and places of
business where card games are played in connection with a business, within
the city, shall close at 11:00 p.m., and remain closed until 6:00 a.m.



(1982 Code, § 110.01)  (Ord. 69-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 110.26  SLAUGHTERHOUSES PROHIBITED.



   (A)   The slaughtering of cattle, sheep, hogs or other animals
within the corporate limits of the city is declared a nuisance.



   (B)   Any building or enclosure which shall or may produce any
unwholesome smell or annoyance to the inhabitants being in the vicinity
thereof or any slaughterhouse for the killing of animals, located within the
corporate limits of the city or within 1/2-mile of the corporate limits
thereof, are each and all declared nuisances.



   (C)   It is declared unlawful for any person or company to slaughter
any animals in the city or to maintain any building, or enclosure therein, or
to construct, maintain and operate any slaughterhouse within the corporate
limits of the city, or without the city within 1/2 mile of the corporate
limits of the city.



(1982 Code, § 110.02)  (Ord. 61-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 110.27  LICENSE REQUIRED; FEES; APPLICATION.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company or
corporation, for the purpose of profit or gain, to erect, maintain, use,
operate or exhibit, or to practice, engage in, do or perform any of the
exhibitions, performances, trades, avocations, businesses, professions,
enterprises or things particularly designated in this chapter, without having
first procured from the city a license to do so, and paid to the city for the
license the sum of money provided herein.



(1982 Code, § 110.10)  (Ord. 64-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord. 77-1932,
passed 2-23-1932)



   (B)   (1)   The license fee to be charged for the purposes herein
designated shall be in sums and shall be issued for periods of time as set
out in the following divisions.



      (2)   All licenses so issued shall plainly set out the time
covered by licenses.



(1982 Code, § 110.11)



   (C)   (1)   Any person desiring any license herein provided for
shall pay to the Clerk-Treasurer the fee hereinbefore provided for, and take
his or her receipt therefore.



      (2)   The applicant shall then present the Clerk-Treasurer
with his or her application for the license desired and for the length of
time desired.



(1982 Code, § 110.12)  Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.28  ROLE OF CLERK-TREASURER.



   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue to the applicant the license
applied and paid upon proper review and approval.



   (B)   The holder of the license and the license shall exhibit the
same on the reasonable request of any police officer.



(1982 Code, § 110.12)



§ 110.29  LICENSES NON-TRANSFERABLE.



   None of the licenses required herein shall be assignable or
transferable by the licensee.



(1982 Code, § 110.12)  (Ord. 64-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 110.30  ORDERLY AND LAWFUL COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.



   It is declared unlawful for any person, firm, company or corporation
holding a license hereunder and exhibiting or controlling by virtue thereof,
any shows, circus or other entertainment and controlling the place of
entertainment to allow any indecent, obscene or immoral language, or picture
or exhibition to be used or to appear in or as a part of entertainment or
show, or to fail to conduct and cause entertainment and place to be conducted
in a lawful and orderly manner.



(1982 Code, § 110.13(A))  Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.31  RESTRICTED HOURS FOR HAWKERS AND PEDDLERS.



   (A)   Persons holding the license herein provided for as peddlers
and hawkers are required to conduct themselves while operating under the
license in a decorous and orderly manner on the streets and on the premises
of persons whose houses they may visit for any display or sale of goods.



   (B)   They shall not visit a premises for any purpose at any time
except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of each day and they
shall not importune persons to examine or buy goods to the annoyance of
persons and peddlers and hawkers, shall at all times while working under the
license, refrain from unusual demonstrations, loud, boisterous, profane or
obscene language.



(1982 Code, § 110.13(B))  Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person, firm, company or corporation that shall violate
any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be
fined in any sum not less than $1 nor more than $100.



   (B)   Each day's continuance in the violation shall constitute a
separate offense.



(1982 Code, § 110.99)  (Ord. 64-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



CHAPTER 111:  CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISED SYSTEMS REGULATIONS



Section



   111.01   Definitions



   111.02   Regulation of basic rates by Board of Public Works and
Safety



   111.03   Procedures for cable rates and charges



   111.04   Rules and regulations of the Board



   111.05   Opportunity for public input



   111.06   Final rate orders



   111.07   Common Council review of final rate orders



   111.08   Hearing before the Common Council



   111.09   Judicial review



   111.10   Certification forms



§ 111.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CABLE ACT.  The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended by
the Cable Television Consumer Protection Act of 1992, an amendment to the
Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. §§ 521 et seq.) as the same may be
amended or supplemented from time to time.



   CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEM, CABLE SYSTEM or SYSTEM.  A facility,
consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal
generation, reception and control equipment that is designed to provide cable
service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple
subscribers within the city, but the term does not include a facility that
serves only to retransmit the television signals of 1 or more television
broadcast stations; a facility that services only subscribers in 1 or more
multiple-unit dwellings under common ownership, control only subscribers in 1
or more multiple-unit dwellings under common ownership, control or
management, unless the facility or facilities use any public right-of-way; a
facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the
provisions of Title II of the Communication Act of 1934, as amended except
that the facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes
of § 621(c) of the Act 147, United States Code § 541(c)] to the extent the
facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to
subscribers; or any facilities of any electric utility used solely for
operating its electric utility systems.



   FRANCHISE.  An initial authorization, or renewal thereof (including a
renewal of an authorization which has been granted subject to § 626 of the
Act (427 U.S.C. § 546), issued by the city whether authorization is
designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract,
certificate, agreement or otherwise, which authorizes the construction
operation of a cable system.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.02  REGULATION OF BASIC RATES BY BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AND SAFETY.



   To the extent permitted by § 623 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. § 543)
and any duly promulgated FCC rate regulations, the City of Brazil, by and
through its Board of Public Works and Safety, shall regulate the basic
service rates and charges for cable television service to subscribers.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.03  PROCEDURES FOR CABLE RATES AND CHARGES.



   The following procedures shall be used to review and approve changes in
basic service rates and charges of the company, or any other franchised cable
television system operating within the corporate limits of the City of Brazil.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.04  RULES AND REGULATIONS OF THE BOARD.



   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall adopt rules and regulations
for the review and regulation of basic service rates and charges for cable
television services provided by the company or other cable television
franchises consistent with the requirements of the Cable Act, FCC rate
regulations and this chapter.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.05  OPPORTUNITY FOR PUBLIC INPUT.



   Regulations shall be promulgated to ensure all interested parties or
persons a reasonable opportunity to express their views regarding any changes
in basic service rates and charges of the company or other cable television
franchises.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.06  FINAL RATE ORDERS.



   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall adopt final rate orders in
accordance with its adopted regulations. Orders shall be final upon adoption,
but may be reviewed by the Common Council upon request by the company or
other cable television franchise, the Board of Public Works and Safety or any
person or interested party who participated orally or by filing written
positions with the Board in the rate proceedings held by it.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.07  COMMON COUNCIL REVIEW OF FINAL RATE ORDERS.



   Review by the Common Council shall be initiated by filing a request
with the Clerk-Treasurer within 15 days of the date of the Board’s final
rate order. The request shall state briefly the reasons for which the review
is being requested.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.08  HEARING BEFORE THE COMMON COUNCIL.



   Within 30 days of the filing of a request, the Common Council shall
hold a hearing on that request. The Council may affirm the final rate order
or remand the order to the Board for further review. If the order is so
remanded, the Board shall hold additional hearings as it deems appropriate
and may either affirm or amend its final rate order.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.09  JUDICIAL REVIEW.



   The order of the Board shall be final subject only to judicial review
as provided by law.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



§ 111.10  CERTIFICATION FORMS.



   The Mayor, or his or her designee, is authorized to execute on behalf
of the city and file with the Federal Communications Commission certification
forms or other instruments as are now or may hereafter be required by the FCC
rate regulations in order to enable the city to regulate basic service rates
and charges.



(Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)



CHAPTER 112:  PEDDLERS, HAWKERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT DEALERS



Section



   112.01   Definitions



   112.02   License fees



   112.03   Surety bond required



   112.04   Exceptions



   112.05   Nuisances declared



   112.06   Solicitation and distribution at or in public places



   112.99   Penalty



§ 112.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   HAWKER.  Anyone who goes about the streets, or elsewhere in the city,
selling or offering for sale, any goods by public outcry, placards, signals
or any other device designed to attract purchasers.



   ITINERANT DEALER.  Any transient person or any person who shall engage
temporarily in the making or selling of any kinds of goods, wares or
merchandise within the city, regardless of whether the goods, wares or
merchandise are peddled from house to house, sold on the streets or other
public places, or sold from any room, branch store, establishment or concern,
building, structure or lot owned, rented or leased for the purpose of
carrying on a temporary business.



   PEDDLER.  Anyone who goes about the streets or from house to house
selling or offering for sale, any goods, wares, merchandise or other articles.



   SOLICITOR.  Any transient person who goes from house to house or from
place to place in the city selling or taking orders for, or offering to sell
or take orders for goods, wares, merchandise, service or any other thing of
value whatsoever.



(1982 Code, § 110.11 (A)(1))  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.02  LICENSE FEES.



   (A)   For each foot peddler, hawker, solicitor or itinerant dealer
of goods, wares or merchandise, or other articles or products, the license
fee shall be:



 



For each day, when taken by the day
 

$10



For each week, when taken by the week
 

$40



For each month, when taken by the month
 

$100



For each year, when taken by the year
 

$300





 



   (B)   For each peddler, hawker, solicitor, itinerant dealer of any
articles or service dispensed from any vehicle or conveyance:



 



For each day, when taken by the day
 

$15



For each week, when taken by the week
 

$60



For each month, when taken by the month
 

$150



For each year, when taken by the year
 

$450





 



(1982 Code, § 110.11(A)(2)(3))  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.03  SURETY BOND REQUIRED.



   (A)   In addition to the license fee required herein, the applicant
for license shall be required to file and deposit with the Clerk-Treasurer a
bond with sureties to be approved by the Clerk-Treasurer in the penal sum of
$5,000 running to the city.



   (B)   The bond shall be for the use and benefit of any purchaser of
any goods, wares or merchandise or service who might have a cause of action
of any nature arising out of a sale against the applicant, or for the payment
of any fines that may be assessed against the applicant, agents or employees
for the violation of this section, or the satisfaction of all cause of action
commenced within 1 year of the date that the sale is made provided that the
aggregate liability of the surety on the bond shall in no event exceed the
amount of the bond and that there shall be no limit of liability against the
foot peddler, solicitor, hawker or itinerant dealer, or the applicant for the
license; provided further, the Clerk-Treasurer in lieu of the bond may accept
proof by the applicant that he or she is presently bonded in the penal sum of
$5,000 or more, which would provide coverage for sales made within the city
during the time of the applicant’s license.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(A)(4))  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.04  EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   The license provided for in § 112.02 shall apply to all
peddlers whether selling goods for cash or immediate delivery, or on orders.
For future delivery or on the installment plan, and to hawkers, solicitors,
itinerant dealers and to all persons assisting in conducting the business;
selling for cash on immediate delivery or taking orders for future delivery
or selling on the installment plan; but this section shall not apply to
agricultural products or fruits cultivated and grown by any peddler, hawker
or itinerant dealer.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(A)(5))



   (B)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale of
newspapers, meat, wood, coal, ice or milk and sales made to dealers by
commercial travelers, and nothing in this section shall be so construed and
enforced to place a burden on interstate commerce.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(A)(5))  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.05  NUISANCES DECLARED.



   The practice or act of going in and on private property or residences,
by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of
merchandise, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or
occupant of the private property or residences, for the purpose of soliciting
orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise, or the rendering or
furnishing of any service or for the purpose of disposing of or peddling,
hawking, rendering or furnishing the same, is declared to be a nuisance and
to be unlawful.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(A)(7))  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.06  SOLICITATION AND DISTRIBUTION AT OR IN PUBLIC PLACES.



   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



      DISTRIBUTION.  The offering, giving, distributing or making
available for distributing of any item of property, including but not limited
to food, drink, leaflets or other written materials, by any person or who is
a bona fide resident of Clay County, Indiana, and any organization which is
located or based in Clay County, Indiana.



      ORGANIZATION.  A person or group of persons who is or are bona
fide residents of Clay County, Indiana; and any corporation, whether
for-profit or not-for-profit; any charitable association, corporation or
entity; any church or other religious-based entity; any civic group or
entity; any service club or entity; any labor union or other labor-based
association or entity; and any municipal, county, state or federal
governmental group, department, agency or entity of any governmental unit, or
other organization which is has an office or locally based location within
Clay County, Indiana, including any national, state or regional charitable,
religious or educational organization.



      PUBLIC PLACE.  Includes any street, alley, highway, sidewalk,
park, public conveyance, building or other place that is open or available to
the general public at large and owned, operated and maintained by any
municipal, county, state or federal governmental unit or entity.



      SOLICITATION.  The requesting, pleading, appealing or the
attempt or exercise of requesting, pleading, appealing for the purpose of
obtaining money or other objects as donations from members of the general
public by any organization, charitable or otherwise, on or within any public
place.



   (B)   Solicitation or distribution. Any person or organization that
desires to engage in the solicitation of money or other objects or to engage
in the distribution of any item of property from or to members of the general
public at or on any public place located within the corporate limits of the
City of Brazil must, prior to solicitation or distribution, register the name
of the person or organization who desires to engage in solicitation or
distribution with the Clerk-Treasurer during normal business hours of that
office at least 2 weeks prior to the intended date of solicitation or
distribution. Registration shall include the following information:



      (1)   The name and address of the organization intending on
engaging in solicitation or distribution;



      (2)   The date(s) of the planned solicitation or distribution;



      (3)   The intended locations(s) of the planned solicitation or
distribution;



      (4)   The purpose of the intended solicitation or
distribution; and



      (5)   The name and address of any person in charge of or
supervising the intended solicitation or distribution.



   (C)   Solicitation or distribution requirements. Any person or
organization engaging in solicitation or distribution pursuant to this
chapter shall comply with the following:



      (1)   Place or carry a flat sign or placard not attached to
any container in a place clearly visible to the general public affected by
the solicitation or distribution that clearly identifies the organization
engaging in the solicitation or distribution to the public affected thereby
and that is clearly readable to persons in vehicles and pedestrian passers-by;



      (2)   The sign or placard shall state the purpose of the
solicitation or distribution;



      (3)   The intended solicitation or distribution shall be
performed only during daylight hours;



      (4)   The person or persons engaging in the solicitation or
distribution shall wear bright colored protective vests that are clearly
visible to motorists and other passers by if the solicitation or distribution
is occurring at or on a public street, road or highway, or the intersection
thereof; and



      (5)   The Police Department may cause any solicitation or
distribution provided for by this ordinance to cease or terminate if any
congested traffic condition or emergency occurs.



   (D)   Solicitation or distribution limited. Any person or
organization engaging in solicitation or distribution within the corporate
limits of the City of Brazil, or desiring to engage in solicitation or
distribution, shall be entitled to do so only 1 time during any calendar
year. Any desired solicitation or distribution more than 1 time per year
shall be at the sole discretion of the Board of Public Works and Safety.



(Ord. 12-2003, passed 9-9-2003)  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.99  PENALTY.



   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a
civil penalty of $100. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
day that a violation occurs or continues.



(Ord. 12-2003, passed 9-9-2003)



CHAPTER 113:  CIRCUSES, EXHIBITIONS AND ENTERTAINMENTS



Section




General Regulations




   113.01   Fees for circuses, parades and wild west shows



   113.02   Animal shows; fees



   113.03   Non-specified exhibitions and entertainments



   113.04   Medicine shows, lectures and exhibitions; fees



   113.05   Street fairs or carnivals



   113.06   Skating rinks, gymnasiums or other sports events



   113.07   Shooting gallery and picture machine; fees



   113.08   Striking, blowing or electric machine; fees



   113.09   Merry-go-round; fees



   113.10   Billiard, pool or other machines or devices



   113.11   Bowling alleys; fees



   113.12   Junk stores or pawn brokers; fees




Specific Regulations




   113.25   Itinerant physician or dentist; fees



   113.26   Itinerant vendor of medicines; fees



   113.27   Itinerant or transient dealer



   113.28   Confectionery or drink wagon vendors; fees



   113.29   Clairvoyant or fortune tellers; fees



   113.30   Gasoline pumps; fees



   113.31   Itinerant or transient photographer; fees



   113.32   Theaters or opera houses



   113.99   Penalty




GENERAL REGULATIONS




§ 113.01  FEES FOR CIRCUSES, PARADES AND WILD WEST SHOWS.



   (A)   For each show commonly known as a circus or as a wild west
show, or any show of similar character, the license fee shall be $60 for each
day.



   (B)   For each parade of a show in the city, the license fee shall
be $60.



   (C)   However, where a show is showing within the city limits and
has procured a license from the city to show, no license fee shall be charged
by the city for a parade of the show.



   (D)   For each show accompanying any show and known as a side show,
the license fee shall be $5.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(C))



   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any circus or side show to exhibit in
the city any indecent or immoral performance. Exhibitions shall be conducted
in an orderly manner and no gambling or any immoral practices shall be
allowed on the grounds occupied or controlled by any show management. In
making any parade of a circus on the streets of the city, the parade shall be
conducted in an orderly and decorous manner and in a manner so as to cause no
injury directly or indirectly to any person or property.



(1982 Code, § 110.13(F))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.02  ANIMAL SHOWS; FEES.



   For each trained animal show or menagerie the license fee shall be:



   (A)   For each day, when taken by the day-$20; and



   (B)   For each week, when taken by the week-$60.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(D))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.03  NON-SPECIFIED EXHIBITIONS AND ENTERTAINMENTS.



   For exhibitions and entertainments not herein, or in any other
ordinance of the city specifically provided for, the license fee shall be:



   (A)   For each day-$15; and



   (B)   For each week-$50.



(1982 Code, § 110.10(E))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.04  MEDICINE SHOWS, LECTURES AND EXHIBITIONS; FEES.



   For shows, exhibitions, lectures, discourses or entertainments for the
sale or advertisement of medicine, medical remedies or methods of treatment
of diseases, or for the sale or advertisement of any article, held in any
room, hall, building on the street or vacant grounds, whether admission is
charged to the same or not, the license fee shall be $10 for each day.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(F))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.05  STREET FAIRS OR CARNIVALS.



   (A)   For every aggregation of shows, exhibitions or entertainments,
commonly known as a street fair or carnival, where aggregation is carried on
under 1 or a common management, the license for the same shall be:



      (1)   For each day, when taken by the day-$25; and



      (2)   For each week of 6 days-$125.



   (B)   Where shows, exhibitions or entertainments are under separate
management, for each of the shows, exhibitions or features of entertainment
constituting aggregation, the license fee shall be:



      (1)   For each day when taken by the day-$6; and



      (2)   For each week, when taken by the week-$25



(1982 Code, § 110.11(G))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.06  SKATING RINKS, GYMNASIUMS OR OTHER SPORTS EVENTS.



   For each commercial skating rink, gymnasium or place where polo,
basketball and like games are played, or other miscellaneous entertainments
are held, the license fee shall be $3 for each day when the license is taken
by the day; $4 for each week when the license is taken by the week; $10 for
each month when taken by the month; and $20 for each year when a license is
taken by the year.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(H))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.07  SHOOTING GALLERY AND PICTURE MACHINE; FEES.



   For each shooting gallery, baby rack and picture machine all combined
or for either of the same separately, the license shall be:



   (A)   For each day-$1;



   (B)   For each week-$5;



   (C)   For each month-$7; and



   (D)   For each year-$20.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(I))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.08  STRIKING, BLOWING OR ELECTRIC MACHINE; FEES.



   For each striking, lifting, pulling, blowing or electric machine:



   (A)   For each day-$1;



   (B)   For each week-$5;



   (C)   For each month-$7; and



   (D)   For each year-$20;



(1982 Code, § 110.11(J))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.09  MERRY-GO-ROUND; FEES.



   (A)   For each merry-go-round:



      (1)   For each day-$3;



      (2)   For each week-$10;



      (3)   For each month-$12; and



      (4)   For each year-$20



   (B)   It is declared unlawful for any person, firm, company or
corporation to conduct or operate the same on any lot or plot of ground
within 1 block from National Avenue, extending from Alabama Street west to
the city limits.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(K))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.10  BILLIARD, POOL OR OTHER MACHINES OR DEVICES.



   No person shall have, keep, operate or maintain for hire or profit in
any public or private place, any billiard, pool or bagatelle table, any
electronic video game, pinball machine and any other mechanical or electrical
gaming machine or device or other machine or device for sports and games,
without obtaining a license specifying the number of tables, games and
devices renewable on or before January 1, 2007 and each year thereafter,
conspicuously displaying the license in the place or establishment where the
table, machine or device is placed or kept, and paying the following annual
license fee:



   (A)   For each billiard, pool or bagatelle table-$25 per table;



   (B)   For each electronic video game, pinball machine, other
mechanical or electronic gaming machine or device or other machine or device
for sports and games-$25 per machine; and



   (C)   For each additional or new table, game, machine or device,
obtained following the issuance of the annual license, a new license must be
obtained by payment of the respective fees, specified in divisions (A) or (B)
above, for each additional table, game or device placed in the establishment
where the same are to be operated.



(Ord. 28-2005, passed 8-24-2005)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.11  BOWLING ALLEYS; FEES.



   For each bowling alley kept for hire:



   (A)   For each day-$1;



   (B)   For each week-$3;



   (C)   For each month-$8; and



   (D)   For each year-$10.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(M))



§ 113.12  JUNK STORES OR PAWN BROKERS; FEES.



   (A)   For carrying on the business of junk stores or pawnbroker, the
license fee shall be $10 for each year.



   (B)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.



      JUNK DEALER.  One who keeps a place of business for the purchase
or sale of junk, old metal, rags, old rope, old canvas, old paper or the like.



      PAWNBROKER.  Any person who loans money on deposit or pledge of
personal property on condition of selling the property or other valuable
things or who deals in the purchasing of personal property on condition of
selling the same back again.



   (C)   Every person, company or corporation holding a license from
the city to conduct the business of a pawnbroker and conducting the business
in the city thereunder, shall make a report in writing to the Marshal on
Monday of each and every week in which report shall be set out every article
of jewelry, watches, rings, silverware, bric-a-brac and other small articles
of property, which have been pawned or sold to or for any purpose left with
the pawnbroker during the calendar week just preceding, and the report shall
give the name and place of residence of the persons so pawning, selling or
depositing any article, and give a full and detailed description of every
article together with the probable value thereof and the time of so leaving
the same. Every junk dealer in the city shall make a report as aforesaid on
Monday of each week in which he or she shall state, set out and describe all
brass or copper that may have been purchased by him or her during the
preceding calendar week, giving the name of the person from whom the same was
purchased. And it is further ordained that no person, firm or corporation
shall conduct the business of junk dealer within 2 city blocks of National
Avenue or within 2 city blocks of any church, hospital or public school
building.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(N))  Penalty, see § 113.99




SPECIFIC REGULATIONS




§ 113.25  ITINERANT PHYSICIAN OR DENTIST; FEES.



   (A)   For each person practicing as an itinerant physician or
dentist, the license fee shall be:



      (1)   For each day-$5;



      (2)   For each week-$25; and



      (3)   For each month-$50.



   (B)   No person holding a license hereunder as an itinerant
physician or dentist, or as a vendor of medicine, shall, in the conduct of
his or her business, make any false representations as regards to diseases,
cures or methods of treatment used by him or her, or as to medicines sold by
him or her.



(1982 Code, § 110.13(O))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.26  ITINERANT VENDOR OF MEDICINES; FEES.



   For each itinerant vendor of medicines at retail, the license fee shall
be:



   (A)   For each day-$1;



   (B)   For each week-$5;



   (C)   For each month-$25; and



   (D)   For each year-$100.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(P))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.27  ITINERANT OR TRANSIENT DEALER.



   For each itinerant or transient dealer in any goods, wares and
merchandise or other articles or products and engaged in selling, or offering
the same for sale, not herein elsewhere classified the license fee shall be:



   (A)   For each day-$3;



   (B)   For each week-$15; and



   (C)   For each month-$50.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(Q))



§ 113.28  CONFECTIONERY OR DRINK WAGON VENDORS; FEES.



   (A)   For each person selling lunch, candy, ice cream, popcorn,
Cracker Jack and other confectionery, or lemonade, or other soft drinks and
fruits on the streets with wagon or otherwise, the fee will be $10 for each 6
months for each and every vehicle used and no license shall be issued for a
period less than 6 months.



   (B)   Any person holding a license hereunder for the purpose of
selling lunch, fruits, confectionery and like articles on the streets, shall
while so working under a license, move along from place to place and not
remain stationary.



(1982 Code, § 110.13(R))



§ 113.29  CLAIRVOYANT OR FORTUNE TELLERS; FEES.



   For each clairvoyant, fortune teller or palmist practicing the same for
hire:



   (A)   For each day-$5;



   (B)   For each week-$25;



   (C)   For each month-$75; and



   (D)   For each year-$125.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(S))



§ 113.30  GASOLINE PUMPS; FEES.



   For each gasoline pump located in the city and being used and operated
in the sale of gasoline at retail or wholesale price, the license fee shall
be $10 per year.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(T))



§ 113.31  ITINERANT OR TRANSIENT PHOTOGRAPHER; FEES.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business
or to exercise the vocation of an itinerant or transient photographer in the
city without having first procured from the city a license to do so and pay
to the city for the license the sums of money hereinafter designated.



   (B)   Any person desiring to procure the license as above provided
for shall pay to the Clerk-Treasurer the fee hereinafter provided, for which
the Clerk-Treasurer shall execute to the applicant his or her receipt. On
presentation of a receipt to the Clerk-Treasurer, the Clerk-Treasurer shall
issue to the applicant a license to conduct the business or vocation of an
itinerant or transient photographer, as the same is hereinafter defined,
within the city for the period of time for which the applicant shall have
paid according to the scale hereinafter set out. The license shall be signed
by the Clerk-Treasurer. The license shall be issued for the period of 1 day
or for any number of days less than 1 week, or for 1 week, or for any number
of weeks less than 1 month, or for 1 month or for any number of months less
than 1 year, according as the same may be applied and paid for and the charge
for the license shall be:



      (1)   For each day-$2;



      (2)   For each week-$10;



      (3)   For each month-$25; and



      (4)   For each year-$100.



   (C)   For the purpose of this section, an ITINERANT PHOTOGRAPHER or
TRANSIENT PHOTOGRAPHER shall be any person who goes about from place to place
in the city taking photographs or pictures of scenes, objects, buildings,
structures, animals or person or groups, assemblages or processions of
persons, for hire or pay, or for the purpose of developing the negatives so
taken and selling the developed picture or negative, or for the purpose of
receiving compensation, or a consideration for a work or picture, in any way.



   (D)   It is declared unlawful for any person so licensed as
hereinbefore provided, or for any person not so licensed, engaged as an
itinerant or transient photographer or acting as so in the city, to take any
flash light picture of any public assemblage or person or persons in any
church, theater, hall, building or other enclosure in the city, and any
person engaged as a photographer in the city is prohibited from taking any
obscene, licentious, indecent or immoral pictures or from taking any snapshot
of any person against the wishes of the person or to his or her annoyance,
except the snapshot be taken to aid in the detection and prosecution of crime.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(U))  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.32  THEATERS OR OPERA HOUSES.



   (A)   Authority is granted to the Clerk-Treasurer for the issuing of
a license by the city, to the owner, lessee or person in control of any
theater, opera house, room, building or other designated place in the city
for show or exhibitions in those places, which license shall be known as a
"house license" and shall be issued for the period of 1 year only. The
license must be secured before shows or exhibitions may take place.



   (B)   The license fee for a license shall be $25.00 for any show
charging an admission of not to exceed $0.05 and $50.00 for any show charging
an admission of not to exceed $0.10 and $75.00 for any show charging an
admission of more than $0.10.



(1982 Code, § 110.11(V))  (Ord. 64-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Am. Ord.
94-1933, passed 11-28-1933; Am. Ord. 5-1972, passed 5-23-1972)



§ 113.99  PENALTY.



   Any person, firm, company or corporation that shall violate any of the
provisions of this chapter shall, on conviction thereof, be subject to a
civil penalty of $50, and each day’s continuance in the violation shall
constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 28-2005, passed 8-24-2005)



CHAPTER 114:  TAXICABS AND COMMERCIAL VEHICLES



Section



   114.01   Commercial vehicle defined



   114.02   Bond, liability contract and insurance requirements



   114.03   Application procedure; sign designation



   114.04   Annual license fee



   114.05   Time and days of operation



   114.06   Legal age for operation of vehicle



   114.07   Receiving and discharging passengers



   114.08   Notification of police of lost articles



   114.09   License revocation by Council and suspension by Mayor



   114.99   Penalty



§ 114.01  COMMERCIAL VEHICLE DEFINED.



   (A)   Every person, firm or corporation operating any motor vehicle
along and on any public street or highway within the city, for the purpose of
affording a means of local street or highway transportation by accepting and
discharging persons as may offer themselves for transportation either at
temporary street or highway parking places or along the course or within the
terminal on which the motor vehicle is or may be running or operating or that
may be operated for the transportation of passengers, from place to place in
or about the city from any street curb, alley or highway stand or stands, or
parking or stopping places, either on calls or otherwise, from so, is
declared to be a commercial motor vehicle for hire.



   (B)   This section does not include motor vehicles owned and
operated by hotel companies or hotel proprietors, between their hotels and
depots, for their exclusive use and benefit in conveying their guests to and
from the same.



(1982 Code, § 113.01)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 114.02  BOND, LIABILITY CONTRACT AND INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   No person, firm or corporation shall operate any commercial
vehicle, and it shall be unlawful to do so, unless there shall have been
filed with the Clerk-Treasurer, duly approved and accepted by the Mayor
thereof, a good and sufficient indemnity surety or indemnity company created
under the laws of the state, or duly authorized to transact business
thereunder, which the bond shall describe the motor vehicle by factory
number, maker’s name, rated seating capacity and number of passengers
capable of being accommodated therein at 1 time, and number of state and city
license under which the same is operated.



   (B)   When the license or either of them are changed by the issuance
of a new one, it shall be indicted on a bond by the attachment of a rider
thereto. The bond shall provide, among other things, that the company issuing
the same shall be liable for and pay all damages including injury to person
or property not exceeding $300,000 to any 1 person, or $300,000 for any 1
accident that may be recovered in any action against the person, firm or
corporation so licensed to operate the commercial vehicle by reason of the
negligent use and operation of the same. However, when any claim has been
made or an action commenced against a person, firm or corporation operating
the commercial vehicle, described in the bond, growing out of an accident by
reason of the operation thereof and while operating hereunder, the person,
firm or corporation shall not further operate the commercial vehicle
hereunder until another bond meeting the requirements of this section shall
have been filed. Or in lieu of the furnishing and filing of the bond the
person, firm or corporation shall have filed with the Clerk-Treasurer a
liability contract of insurance issued him or her by an insurance company
organized under the laws of the state, or authorized to transact business
herein, providing among other things, for the payment of any final judgment
that may be rendered against the insured for damages to property or bodily
injury or death to others resulting from accident or collision for which the
person, firm or corporation may be liable as a common carrier while operating
the commercial vehicle described therein within the provisions hereof by
reason of and growing out of the negligent operation of the commercial
vehicle.



   (C)   The bond or insurance shall be in a sum not less than $300,000
to cover liability to property or person and $300,000 to cover liability and
damages for property or persons as a result of any 1 accident.



   (D)   The policy contract of insurance or bond shall further, among
other things, provide that in the event of a final judgment being rendered or
sustained against the insured, within the provisions of the company’s
assumed liability, payment thereof to the insured shall not be made, without
the written consent of the person recovering the same, within a period of 1
year from the date the judgment was finally rendered or sustained.
Thereafter, if not paid, the person recovering judgment may be subrogated to
all of the rights and subject to the conditions of the insured and may
directly enforce the company's liability, if it existed, and the contract
shall further provide that the stipulations and the conditions therein
contained which refer to the insured’s conduct with the company and
company’s conduct with the insured, in reference to accidents and claims
thereunder and any rules governing the conduct of the insured or company or
any branch thereof shall not be a defense in any action brought to enforce a
liability under a policy or bond by any person other than the insured. It
shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation to keep the insurance
or bond in force during the full period of time for which he or she may be
operating thereunder, and in case the policy contract of insurance or bond is
canceled the city shall be notified and the contract shall so provide by
suitable provision therein, and if any bond so filed shall become inoperative
or the policy of insurance canceled, the commercial vehicle shall not be
operated until a bond or policy of insurance meeting the requirements of this
section shall have been filed.



(Am. Ord. 9-2004, passed 5-11-2004)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.03  APPLICATION PROCEDURE; SIGN DESIGNATION.



   (A)   A bond or policy contract of insurance shall be accompanied by
an application on blanks furnished by the city, stating the name, age, (if an
individual) business and residence of the applicant and the length of time in
which he or she has operated motor driven vehicles, the territory within
which it is proposed to operate, the commercial vehicle or the manner or
method of operation and the proposed hours, the character of operation and
the rate of fare to be charged for carriage therein. It shall state the
license number and a description of the vehicle to be used by factory number
and maker’s name, rated seating capacity and number of persons capable of
being carried therein at 1 time.



   (B)   If the application and bond or policy contract of insurance
compares with the provisions hereinbefore set forth and the applicant has
paid the hereinafter license fee, the Clerk-Treasurer shall thereupon issue
to the applicant a license permitting the operating of the commercial vehicle
therein described under the provisions of this chapter, which license shall
be numbered severally, contain the number of the motor vehicle, state license
number, date of its issuance and expiration thereof. It shall be the duty of
the person, firm or corporation receiving the license, to plainly mark, in a
permanent manner, each commercial vehicle covered thereby by painting or
securely fastening on the sides thereof in letters not less than 2 inches in
height and the letters of which shall be not less than 1/4-inch in width, the
words "Bonded Carrier" or "Insured Carrier" (as the case may be) following by
the city license number, so that all commercial vehicles claimed to be
operated under the provisions of this division may be readily identified.



(1982 Code, § 113.03)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
114.99



§ 114.04  ANNUAL LICENSE FEE.



   Any person, firm or corporation desiring to obtain a license hereunder
shall pay to the City Clerk-Treasurer for the benefit of the city for each
commercial vehicle to be so driven or operated an annual license fee of $10.



(1982 Code, § 113.04)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
114.99



§ 114.05  TIME AND DAYS OF OPERATION.



   All vehicles operating under this chapter shall be operated at least 5
days out of each and every week, and shall be operated at least 8 hours on
each of the days so required to be operated.



(1982 Code, § 113.05)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
114.99



§ 114.06  LEGAL AGE FOR OPERATION OF VEHICLE.



   No license shall be issued to any person under the age of 18 years, and
it shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to drive or
operate any commercial vehicle or for any licensee to cause or permit any
person, underage, to drive or operate a commercial vehicle so licensed for
the purpose herein provided.



(1982 Code, § 113.06)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
114.99



§ 114.07  RECEIVING AND DISCHARGING PASSENGERS.



   Every person, firm or corporation operating commercial vehicles
hereunder, shall receive and discharge passengers as close to the right-hand
curb of streets as possible, and shall at all times keep vehicle so used in a
clean and sanitary condition, and no person shall be permitted to sit or
stand on the running board or fenders, or sit in the doors or door while same
is in motion. The left rear door, while a commercial vehicle is being
operated hereunder, shall be locked or otherwise fastened, so that it cannot
be opened. The rear or tonneau part of every commercial vehicle, while in
operation, shall be lighted during the night time when a winter top is used
thereon and the sides thereof closed.



(1982 Code, § 113.07)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
114.99



§ 114.08  NOTIFICATION OF POLICE OF LOST ARTICLES.



   It shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation operating
under the provisions hereof to promptly notify the Police Department of all
articles found in any commercial vehicles operated by them, a description
thereof, where they are kept and where they may be found so as to be returned
to the owner.



(1982 Code, § 113.08)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 114.09  LICENSE REVOCATION BY COUNCIL AND SUSPENSION BY MAYOR.



   (A)   The Common Council may revoke any license issued hereunder on
notice to the licensee, and after a due hearing for the violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter.



   (B)   When any person has been convicted for 3 successive times
within a period of 6 months of violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter or any other ordinance of the city regulating street travel of motor
vehicles, the license of the person may be, by the Mayor, suspended for a
period not to exceed 90 days nor less that 30 days during which time the
commercial vehicles shall not be operated hereunder.



   (C)   The licensee may appeal from suspension to the Common Council
and, on hearing, the Common Council in its discretion may either affirm or
overrule the suspension of the Mayor; if overruled, the commercial vehicle
may continue operating under the license.



(1982 Code, § 113.10)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



§ 114.99  PENALTY.



   Any person, firm or corporation on conviction for the violation of or
failure to comply with any provisions of this chapter shall be fined in any
sum not less than $5 and not more than $25 for each and every offense
hereunder.



(1982 Code, § 113.99)  (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



CHAPTER 115:  GASOLINE STATION REGULATIONS



Section



   115.01   Written consent for gasoline stations



   115.02   Description and location; removal or relocation



   115.03   Specification of exact location



   115.04   Restrictions on city square



   115.99   Penalty



§ 115.01  WRITTEN CONSENT FOR GASOLINE STATIONS.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, company or corporation to
hereafter install any gasoline filling station in any street, alley or
sidewalk or other public place, or in any place where an installation is made
for the purpose of selling gasoline or oil or both at retail or wholesale
prices within the city without having first obtained the written consent of
the Street and Alley Committee or Common Council in writing signed by the
Chairperson of the Committee.



(1982 Code, § 114.01)  (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
115.99



§ 115.02  DESCRIPTION AND LOCATION; REMOVAL OR RELOCATION.



   (A)   Before locating any gasoline station filling station, the
person, company or corporation desiring to do so shall give notice in writing
to the Committee or to the Common Council of his or her desire to locate a
gasoline filling station and shall set out in a notice a description of the
place on which it is desired to locate the same.



   (B)   The Street and Alley Committee or the city engineer, together
with the person or the representative of the company or corporation, shall go
over the street, alley or public place named in the notice and the committee,
city engineer shall designate the exact place where the filling station shall
be erected and maintained, subject however, to future removal or relocation
on reasonable notice from the city in the event of reasonable requirements of
street or other public improvements or other reasonable necessity for the
removal or relocation of the filling station; and the city shall be the sole
judge of the reasonable necessity for the removal or relocation of any
filling station at any subsequent time.



(1982 Code, § 114.02)  (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
115.99



§ 115.03  SPECIFICATION OF EXACT LOCATION.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a person, company or corporation to
install any filling station at a point other than that designated by the
committee or city engineer, and the written permit provided for in § 115.02
above shall specify the exact location of the filling station so designated
by the Committee or city engineer and it is provided, that in case of the
installation of the same at a point other than the place designated as
aforesaid or in case there should exist a reasonable necessity for the
removal or relocation of any filling station for reasons as set out in §
115.02 hereof.



   (B)   If the person, company or corporation so installing any
filling station shall fail or refuse after reasonable notice, to remove or
relocate the filling station, then in any event, the city, through its
officers and officials and employees, shall have the right to remove or
relocate any filling station and the costs of the removal or relocation may
be recovered in any court of competent jurisdiction by the city from the
person, company or corporation owning the station and failing to obey the
city’s notice to relocate or remove the same.



(1982 Code, § 114.03)  (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
115.99



§ 115.04  RESTRICTIONS ON CITY SQUARE.



   It is provided that there shall be only 1 gasoline filling station
located and installed in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place on
either side of any city square.



(1982 Code, § 114.04)  (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931)  Penalty, see §
115.99



§ 115.99  PENALTY.



   Any person or corporation violating any of the provisions of this
chapter shall, on conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not less than $1 or
more than $100 and each day’s continuance in the violation shall constitute
a separate offense.



(1982 Code, § 114.99)  (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931)



TITLE XIII: GENERAL OFFENSES



   Chapter



      130.   CURFEW FOR MINORS



CHAPTER 130:  CURFEW FOR MINORS



Section



   130.01   Purpose of curfew



   130.02   Definitions



   130.03   Violation of restricted curfew hours



   130.04   Defense



   130.05   Enforcement



   130.99   Penalty



§ 130.01  PURPOSE OF CURFEW.



   (A)   After review of relevant information provided by the Brazil
Police Department, the Common Council has deemed it necessary to enact
restricted curfew hours for minors in the City of Brazil due to increased
complaints of thefts, criminal mischief and other juvenile involvement by
children under 18 years of age.



   (B)   The purpose of this chapter is to protect minors from
victimization and exposure to criminal activity during late night hours, to
promote the role of parents in the raising and control of their children, to
promote the health, safety and welfare of persons and property in the City of
Brazil and promote the peace, order and safety of cemeteries and other
facilities used to memorialize the dead.



(Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)



§ 130.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DIRECT ROUTE.  The shortest reasonable path of travel or a commonly
used route to reach a final destination without any detour or stop along the
way.



   EMERGENCY.  Any unforseen circumstances or combination of
circumstances, or state or condition resulting therefrom that requires or
calls for immediate action to safeguard life, limb or property. The term
includes, but is not limited to, a fire, natural disaster, an automobile
accident or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent or respond to
any serious bodily injury or death or serious property damage.



   ESTABLISHMENT.  Any privately-owned place of business within the
corporate limits of the City of Brazil operated for profit to which the
public is invited, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or
entertainment (such as movie theater, pool or billiard establishment, concert
hall, video machine establishment and the like).



   MINOR.  Any person under 18 years of age.



   OFFICER.  A police officer or other law enforcement officer charged
with the duty of enforcing and having jurisdiction to enforce the laws of the
State of Indiana and the ordinances of the City of Brazil.



   OWNER/OPERATOR.  Any person or entity operating, managing or
conducting business in any establishment, and the employees, agents, officers
or representatives thereof (including a sole proprietorship, partnership,
association or corporation).



   PARENT.  A person who is a natural or biological mother or father,
adoptive parent, foster parent or stepparent of another person who has
custody or control of a minor, or other person to whom legal custody of a
minor has been given by court order.



   PUBLIC PLACE.  A place to which the public or a substantial group of
the public has access, including, but not limited to, streets, highways,
roads, alleys or parking lots, transportation facilities, theaters,
restaurants, shops, bowling alleys, schools and school grounds, museums,
playgrounds, places of business and amusement, swimming pools, cemetery,
community centers, YMCA, hospitals, office buildings, governmental buildings
and property and any other areas that are open to or accessible to the public.



   RESTRICTED CURFEW HOURS. 



      (1)   For a minor 15, 16 or 17 years of age: after 11:00 p.m.
on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, and before 5:00 a.m.
on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday, and between 1:00 a.m. and
5:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday;



      (2)   For a minor less than 15 years of age: after 11:00 p.m.
or before 5:00 a.m. on any day; and



      (3)   For a minor in a cemetery or other facility used to
memorialize the dead within the corporate limits of the City of Brazil: after
9:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m. on any day.



(Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)



§ 130.03  VIOLATION OF RESTRICTED CURFEW HOURS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for a
minor to be or remain in or upon any public place or in or upon the premises
of any establishment within the corporate limits of the City of Brazil during
the restricted curfew hours, unless:



      (1)   The minor is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian;



      (2)   The minor is involved in an emergency;



      (3)   The minor is engaged in a lawful employment activity, or
is going to or returning home from the activity by using a direct route
without detour or stop;



      (4)   The minor is on the sidewalk directly abutting a place
where the minor resides with a parent or guardian;



      (5)   The minor is attending or traveling to or from by direct
route, a legal school, religious or recreational activity that is supervised
by adults sponsored by a school, governmental entity, civic organization or
other similar entity;



      (6)   The minor is on an errand at the direction of a parent
or guardian and the minor has in his or her possession a writing signed by
the parent or guardian containing the following information: name, signature,
address and telephone number of the parent or guardian authorizing the
errand, the name of the minor, the minor’s destination and the date and
time that the minor is authorized to be engaged in the errand;



      (7)   The minor is exercising his or her First Amendment
rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise
of religion, freedom of speech and right of assembly; however, the mere
presence or “hanging out” of minors in public places, or the aimless
cruising of city streets are not considered to be within the protection of
the First Amendment; or



      (8)   The minor is married and emancipated.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for a
parent or guardian of a minor who knowingly permits, or by insufficient
control allows, the minor to be or remain in any public place or
establishment within the corporate limits of the City of Brazil during the
restricted curfews hours.



      (1)   For purposes of this division (division (B)) the term
KNOWINGLY includes knowledge that a parent should reasonably be expected to
have concerning the whereabouts of the minor in that parent’s custody.



      (2)   It is the intent of this division to hold a neglectful
or careless parent to a reasonable community standard of parental
responsibility, and it shall be no defense that a parent was indifferent to
the activities or conduct or whereabouts of his or her minor child.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for an
owner/operator of an establishment to knowingly allow a minor to be or remain
upon the premises of an establishment during the restricted curfew hours. For
purposes of this division, the term KNOWINGLY includes knowledge that an
owner/operator should reasonably be expected to have concerning the patrons
of the establishment, and the standard for KNOWINGLY shall be whether a
reasonable person in the owner/operator’s position should have known that
the patron was a minor in violation of the terms of this chapter.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any
person 18 years of age or older to aid and abet a minor in violating the
terms of this chapter, or for a parent or guardian to refuse to take custody
during the restricted curfew hours of a minor for whom the parent or guardian
is responsible.



(Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)  Penalty, see § 130.99



§ 130.04  DEFENSE.



   It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this chapter
when the owner/operator of an establishment, or any employee, officer, agent
or representative thereof, or the person in charge of or overseeing a public
place, promptly notified the Police Department that a minor was present on
the premises of the establishment during the restricted curfew hours and
refused to leave.



(Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)  Penalty, see § 130.99



§ 130.05  ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)   Before taking any official enforcement action pursuant to this
chapter, the officer shall undertake an immediate investigation to determine
whether or not a violation of this chapter has occurred, including asking the
minor’s name, address, age, name of parent(s) or guardian, the reason for
being in a public place or establishment during the restricted curfew hours
and requesting any writing from the minor’s parents or guardian as provided
for in this chapter.



   (B)   If the officer determines that a violation has occurred, the
officer shall issue an ordinance violation citation to the minor, to the
parent or guardian of the minor who likewise is in violation, to the
owner/operator of an establishment who is in violation or any other person
who is in violation of this chapter, charging the violator(s) with a
violation of this chapter.



(Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)  Penalty, see § 130.99



§ 130.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of § 130.01 shall be fined not
less than $1 nor more than $100.



   (B)   Whoever violates any provision of § 130.03 shall be fined not
less than $1 nor more than $10.



   (C)   Whoever violates any provision of § 130.04 shall be fined not
less than $1 nor more than $25.



   (D)   Whoever violates any provision of § 130.05 shall be fined not
less than $5 nor more than $100.



   (E)   Whoever violates any provision of § 130.06 shall be fined not
more than $10.



   (F)   For violations of this chapter, a separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues.



   (G)   Any minor 15 to 17 years of age who violates § 130.03(A)
shall be subject to a civil penalty of $25.



   (H)   Any minor under the age of 15 years who violates § 130.03(A)
shall be subject to a civil penalty of $50.



   (I)   Any minor who violates § 130.03(A) in a cemetery or other
facility used to memorialize the dead shall be subject to a civil penalty of
$100.



   (J)   Any parent or guardian of a minor who violates § 130.03(B)
shall be subject to a civil penalty of $50.



   (K)   Any person or entity who violates §§ 130.03(C) or (D) shall
be subject to a civil penalty of $50.



   (L)   For each violation of § 130.03 by any minor, parent or
guardian of a minor, owner/operator of an establishment, or any other person
within 90 days of a previous violation, the violator shall be subject to a
civil penalty of $100.



   (M)   Any person violating the terms of this chapter shall pay the
appropriate penalty at the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer within 30 days
from the date of the citation. If the penalty is not paid within 30 days, the
Clerk-Treasurer shall refer the citation to the City Attorney for filing and
prosecution of the citation in a court of competent jurisdiction over
ordinance violations located in the county.



(Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)



TITLE XV: LAND USAGE
